questions.text: A patient presents with fever, soar throat, and dyspnea. The examination finding of the oral cavity is shown below. What will be the media used to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with pseudomembrane over tonsil is suggestive of diphtheria caused by Corynebacterium diphtheria. Loeffler's serum slope is the medium for diagnosis of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. 

Loeffler's serum slope (shown in the image below) is an enriched medium for the growth of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. It is not a selective medium as other organisms can also grow on this medium. Rapid growth occurs within 6-8 hours. Colonies appear at first as small, opaque discs. They increase in size on continued incubation and may acquire a yellow tint.

Corynebacterium diphtheria (also called Klebs-Loeffler bacillus) is a gram-positive bacillus with clubbing at both ends. They possess characteristic polymetaphosphate granules also called metachromatic granules.

Diphtheria is characterized by mild fever, sore throat, difficulty swallowing, malaise, loss of appetite, and hoarseness (if the larynx is involved). The hallmark is a grey-white pseudomembrane over the mucous lining of the tonsils (most commonly), pharynx, larynx, or nares. It is tightly adherent to the underlying tissue, and any attempt to dislodge the membrane may cause bleeding. 

A few patients develop massive swelling of the tonsils and present with bull-neck diphtheria, due to edema of the submandibular and paratracheal region.

Other options:

Lowenstein-Jenson medium is shown in the given image. It is a selective medium used for Mycobacterium tuberculosis culture. Malachite green imparts a green colour and makes Lowenstein Jenson medium a selective media by inhibiting other bacteria. 

Middlebrook’s media is a liquid culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It is shown in the image below.

Thayer-Martin medium is shown in the image below. It is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The antimicrobials present in it, suppress the growth of other commensal organisms which may inhibit the growth of N.gonorrhoeae. It contains antimicrobials like vancomycin, colistin, and nystatin in chocolate agar.

questions.text: A young athlete complains of burning retrosternal pain on lying down at night. ECG reveals sinus arrhythmia. What is the primary cause of this condition?

choices.text: Changes in vagal tone during breathing
Presence of ectopic foci in the left atrium

questions.solution:
Amongst the given options, the primary cause of sinus arrhythmia is changes in vagal tone during breathing.

Sinus arrhythmia is a physiological fluctuation in heart rate during respiration. It is commonly seen in young athletes. The heart rate increases during inspiration and decreases during expiration, especially when the depth of breathing is increased. This is due to the fluctuations in parasympathetic output to the heart. 

During inspiration, the stretch receptors of the lungs send signals to the vagus nerves. The vagi then inhibits the cardiac inhibitory area of the medulla oblongata. The tonic vagal tone thus decreases, and the heart rate increases. The opposite occurs during expiration, with a resultant increase in vagal tone. The cardiac inhibitory area also receives signals from the medullary respiratory center.  

Other options:

Option B: Cardiac output is directly proportional to preload over a certain range. Preload can be determined by venous return, which increases in the supine position as compared to standing. Thus, the cardiac output increases when supine as compared to standing.

Option C: Degeneration of the sino-atrial node is a cause of sick sinus syndrome. It is more commonly seen in elderly people. Sick sinus syndrome includes sinus bradycardia, sinus tachycardia and sinus bradycardia-tachycardia. 

Option D: Ectopic foci in the atrium result in premature atrial contractions (PACs). In this, the P wave occurs too soon in the cardiac cycle, followed by a compensatory pause. They can occur in healthy people, especially athletes.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man complains of jet lag whenever he flies long distances. He was prescribed Ramelteon. Where are the receptors for this drug situated?
questions.solution:
Ramelteon is a synthetic analogue of melatonin. Melatonin G-protein coupled receptors (MT1 and MT2) are found on neurons in the suprachiasmatic nucleus. 

There are two melatonin receptors, MT1 and MT2, in the suprachiasmatic nucleus where MT1 receptors promote the sleep onset and MT2 receptors change the timing of the circadian system. The suprachiasmatic nucleus functions as the principal pacemaker, or time clock, for circadian rhythms.

The pacemaker receives input from the eyes and many other parts of the nervous system, and these inputs mediate the effects exerted by the external environment (retinohypothalamic tract). One output of the pacemaker goes to the pineal gland, a gland within the brain that secretes the hormone melatonin. These neural signals cause the pineal gland to secrete melatonin during darkness but not during daylight.

Diurnal variation of ACTH also depends on the suprachiasmatic nucleus. The secretory rates of ACTH and cortisol are high in the early morning but low in the late evening. This effect results from a 24-hour cyclical alteration in the signals from the suprachiasmatic nucleus of the hypothalamus that cause cortisol secretion. When a person changes daily sleeping habits, the cycle changes correspondingly.

Other options -

Option A - Ventromedial hypothalamic nucleus, also known as the satiety center gives a sense of satisfaction or fullness and inhibits the feeding center. 

Option B - Anterior hypothalamic nuclei are responsible for regulating the body temperature. 

Option C - The lateral nuclei of the hypothalamus serve as a feeding center and operates by exciting the motor drives to search for food.

questions.text: A mother brings her 9-year-old child with complaints of polyuria. On examination, he has growth failure and bitemporal hemianopia. Laboratory evaluation reveals low urine osmolality and high plasma osmolality. Findings on the MRI brain are given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with MRI showing intracranial mass with foci of calcification at sella turcica and the laboratory findings suggestive of diabetes insipidus point to a diagnosis of craniopharyngioma.

Craniopharyngiomas are tumors that arise from the remnants of Rathke’s pouch. It is an intracranial space-occupying lesion. It has bimodal age of presentation. Children usually present with frequent headaches, short stature, bitemporal hemianopsia (due to optic chiasm compression), and polyuria.

These tumors are usually large and heterogeneous, displaying both solid and cystic components, and occur within the suprasellar area. The cysts contain a cholesterol-rich, thick brownish-yellow fluid and are compared to machine oil. They also show radiologically demonstrable calcification.

Treatment of central diabetes insipidus caused by craniopharyngioma includes supplementation with vasopressin analogs desmopressin (DDAVP) and resection of the tumor.

Other options:

Option B: Germinomas of the pituitary stalk also cause central diabetes insipidus. However, they are often missed in routine neuroimaging. 

Option C: Pituitary microadenomas usually present incidentally or with endocrine effects. They are <10mm in size and the tumor is confined to the sella. Visual field deficits are usually caused by pituitary macroadenomas. 

Option D: Langerhans cell histiocytosis is a rare cause of central diabetes insipidus. Symptoms include dermatological manifestations such as red, scaly papules, pain, and swelling in the limbs, characteristic bony lesions, and disseminated lymph node enlargement.

questions.text: Dengue is caused by which of the following species of mosquitoes?
questions.solution:
Dengue is called by mosquitoes belonging to the Aedes species. As shown in the image below, it can be identified with the stripes on the legs and body. They are also called tiger mosquitoes because of their stripped patterns.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution.
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes and Mansonia.
  • Flight range varies up to 11 kms, except Aedes for which it is 100 metres.
  • Life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days.
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen.

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in eliciting tickle and itch sensations?
questions.solution:
Itch and tickle sensations are elicited by the stimulation of free nerve endings of unmyelinated type C nerve fibers.

The free nerve ends are rapidly adapting mechanoreceptors and are present only in the superficial layers of the skin. After these fibers synapse in the spinal cord, the sensations are carried in the contralateral anterolateral spinothalamic tract.

The same type-C fibers are also involved in carrying sensations of slow pain. The itch sensation calls attention to mild surface stimuli such as a flea crawling on the skin or a fly about to bite. These signals later activate the scratch reflex. This way by scratching one gets relieved of the itch. Sometimes, this scratching action can be strong enough to elicit pain. These pain signals suppress the itch signals in the cord by lateral inhibition.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a grievous hurt?

choices.text: 7 days admission in yellow zone of hospital

questions.solution:
Among the options provided, a seven-day admission in the yellow zone of the hospital is not an example of grievous hurt, but any hurt which causes the sufferer to be in severe body pain for 15 days is considered to be an example of grievous hurt.

Grievous hurt (Sec 116 BNS) is inflicted voluntarily on another person and comprises any of the eight kinds (clauses) enumerated below:

Clause 1 — Emasculation.
Clause 2 — Permanent privation of the sight of either eye. 
Clause 3 — Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear.
Clause 4 — Privation of any member or joint.
Clause 5 — Destruction or permanent impairment of powers of any member or joint.
Clause 6 — Permanent disfigurement of head or face.
Clause 7 — Fracture or dislocation of bone or tooth.
Clause 8 — Any hurt that endangers life or causes the sufferer to be in severe bodily pain or unable to follow his or her ordinary pursuits for 15 days.

Punishment for grievous hurt :

BNS Section 117(2) - previously, IPC 325: Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt –imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
BNS Section 118(2) - previously, IPC 326: Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapons or means—life imprisonment or imprisonment of a minimum of one year, extendable up to ten years, and fine.

Related IPC's:

BNS Section 115(1) - previously, IPC 321: Voluntarily causing hurt.
BNS Section 117(1) - previously, IPC 322: Voluntarily causing grievous hurt.
BNS Section 115(2) - previously, IPC 323: Punishment for voluntarily causing hurt: Imprisonment up to one year, or with a fine up to one thousand rupees or both.
BNS Section 118(1) - previously, IPC 324: Voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous weapons or means (3 years imprisonment) or with fine or both.

questions.text: The urban area of Delhi has 4000 population with different religions. Research is being done to study the dietary habits of the population. Which of the following techniques can be used to obtain a study sample?
questions.solution:
Stratified random sampling is the ideal sampling method for this study.

In stratified random sampling, the population is first divided into homogeneous groups or strata which in this case would be religion. Random samples are drawn from each stratum such that the sample represents the population from all strata.

In this case, the researcher wants to conduct a dietary survey on a population with people of different religions (heterogeneous population). The best method to obtain a sample is to stratify them based on religion and choose a set number of people from each religion so that the final sample represents people from all the religions.

Other options:

Option A: Cluster random sampling involves grouping the population into clusters which contain a set number of people(example a cluster of 3) and selecting few clusters to make the sample for study.

Option C: In simple random sampling people are randomly selected after assigning a number to each individual in the population. In this study with people of different religions, making a simple selection would not provide a sample that equally represents people from all religion.

Option D: Systematic random sampling involves numbering the study population and selecting individual at a regular interval like every 5th or every 10th.

Related Pearl: Sampling

1. Simple random sampling

  • In simple random sampling, samples are drawn in such a way that every element in a population has equal chances of being included.
  • A random is defined by the method of picking the sample and not the outcome.
  • For example, picking 4 random cards from a bag full of cards.

2. Stratified random sampling

  • In stratified random sampling, the population is first divided into homogeneous groups, or strata. From these strata, random samples are drawn.
  • For example, dividing a population into the strata of men, women and children and then picking samples randomly from these strata.

3. Cluster sampling

  • In cluster sampling, the population is divided into internally heterogeneous groups. Then a simple random sampling is done of these clusters and taken as the samples.
  • In other words, the clusters are the sampling unit.
  • For example, if a researcher wants to do a study on 100 doctors working in hospitals in Bangalore, he would select a cluster of 10 hospitals (clusters) and then take 10 doctors from each hospital as part his sample.
  • This is usually done when large scale simple random sampling or stratified sampling is laborious or expensive.
  • This is the method used in assessing immunization status of children.
  • Cluster sampling involves design effect, which is an adjustment to allow for design structure. It aids in correlation between clusters.
  • Multistage sampling is a form of cluster sampling, where sampling clusters are chosen from the already divided clusters.

4. Systematic random sampling

  • In systematic sampling, there is a systematic pattern to selecting the elements of a sample.
  • For example, every 10th person to be admitted to the hospital can be selected or every 3rd baby to be born can be selected.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with complaints of daydreaming in the class as reported by his teacher. Examination revealed that the child had episodes of sudden brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control, which was induced by hyperventilation.  Such episodes lasted for a few seconds, and there was no post-ictal confusion. The child is most likely suffering from
questions.solution:
Sudden, brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control and no post-ictal confusion is seen in Absence seizures. Usually, the seizure lasts only a few seconds.

The seizures may occur about 100 times a day, and the child is unaware. The seizures are so subtle, that may go unrecognized by parents. Most common complaints include "daydreaming" and a decline in school performance recognized by a teacher. The seizures can be provoked by hyperventilation.

EEG shows generalized symmetric 3 Hz spike and wave pattern. Hyperventilation provokes these EEG discharges and seizures.

Other options:

Option A: Syncope is defined as transient, self-limited loss of consciousness due to a sudden decrease in cerebral blood flow. There is a loss of postural control, and patients may faint.

Option B: Myoclonic seizures have preserved consciousness. They involve a sudden brief jerking movement involving the entire body or a part of it.

Option C: Atonic seizures are characterized by a sudden loss of postural control.

questions.text: Which of the following is the defective DNA repair mechanism seen in patients with Severe Combined Immuno Deficiency (SCID)?
questions.solution:
SCID is associated with a defective Non-Homologous End Joining (NHEJ).

Non-homologous end-joining (NHEJ) is a mechanism by which a group of proteins mediates the recognition, processing, and direct ligation of the ends of two DNA fragments where a double-strand break in DNA has occurred. This is in contrast to homologous repair (HR), another mechanism, where an undamaged homologous DNA template is required to replace an adjacent damaged one.

NHEJ deficiency confers combined immunodeficiency due to a failure to carry out recombination efficiently. NHEJ also functions in class switch recombination, another step enhancing T and B cell diversity.

Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)

  • Defects in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses.
  • Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including Candida albicans, Pneumocystis jirovecii, Pseudomonas species, cytomegalovirus, varicella, etc.
  • The most common form is X-linked SCID, and hence, SCID is more common in boys than in girls. The genetic defect in the X-linked form is a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors.
  • The most common cause of autosomal-recessive SCID is a deficiency of the adenosine deaminase (ADA) enzyme.
  • other gene mutations that can be seen in SCID are JAK3, RAG1, IL-7R, etc.

Related Pearl: Human Diseases of DNA Damage Repair

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl, weighing around 15kg is brought to the OPD with complaints of 7-8 episodes of loose stools since morning. On examination, she is alert and active. Her capillary refill time is <2 sec and on skin pinch, there is instant recoil . What is the amount of oral rehydration solution that you would advise in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The amount of oral rehydration solution given to the child in this scenario is 150ml after every loose stool.(Option A)

The given clinical scenario of a child with loose stools, normal sensorium and normal skin turgor indicates that there is no or minimal dehydration in this child according to IMNCI(Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness)guidelines. Plan A is followed for minimal or no dehydration conditions.

Management includes in addition to the daily fluid requirement according to weight of the child calculated by Holiday-Segar formula , oral rehydration solutions in the form of WHO-ORS or home-based oral rehydration solutions in the form of yoghurt drinks, vegetable soups or green coconut water should be given after every loose stool episode as follows -

Age

Amount of ORS to be given after each loose stool (Plan A)

 ORS to provide for home use(Plan A)
<24 months 50-100 ml 500ml/day
2-10 years 100-200 ml 1000ml/day
>10 years

 As much as the child tolerates 2000ml/day

Holiday-Segar formula - The daily fluid requirement in children according to weight -

Upto 10kg - 100ml/kg 

10-20 kg - 50ml/kg

> 20kg - 20ml/kg 

In the above example , the daily fluid requirement is (10 x 100ml) + (5 x 50ml)  = 1250 ml per day.

questions.text: An 8 year old girl was brought to the hospital after her parents noticed blood in her stools. Physical examination showed the below finding. Small bowel radiography and histopathology showed multiple, small- to medium-sized hamartomatous polyps. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of blood in stools, mucocutaneous pigmentation, and hamartomatous small to medium-sized polyps are suggestive of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation.

The hyperpigmentation typically appears as dark blue to brown macules on the lips, nostrils, buccal mucosa, palmar surfaces of the hands, genitalia, and perianal region. During later life, there is a risk for gastric and small intestinal cancers, and subsequently for colon, pancreatic, breast, lung, ovarian, and uterine cancers.

Germline mutations in the gene STK11 are present in approximately half of the individuals with familial Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

Histopathology shows the characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by the normal-appearing intestinal epithelium (as shown below).

Other options:

Option A: Juvenile polyps are the focal malformations of the epithelium or the lamina propria. They occur in children less than 5 years of age. Microscopy of the polyp reveals dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory debris. 

Option B: Turcot syndrome is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis and constitutes colorectal polyps and brain tumors like medulloblastomas and glioblastomas.

Option D: Lynch syndrome, also called hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC) syndrome, is associated with cecum and colon carcinomas. It is a DNA mismatch repair defect. They are also at an increased risk of developing cancers of the endometrium, stomach, ovary, ureters, brain, small bowel, hepatobiliary tract, pancreas, and skin.

questions.text: All the following are recommendations of 	Kartar Singh committee except ________.

choices.text: One basic health worker per 10,000 population
Each sub-centre to have one male and one female health worker

questions.solution:
The recommendation of One basic health worker per 10,000 population  was given by Chadah Committee of 1963.

All the other recommendations were given by the Kartar Singh Committee.

Kartar Singh Committee,1973

The Government of India formed a Committee in 1972 known as ''The Committee on Multipurpose Workers under Health and Family Planning" under the Chairmanship of Kartar Singh and the report was submitted in 1973. Its recommendations were

  • Recommended male and female health workers
  • 1 PHC for 50,000 population
  • Each PHC to have 16 sub-centres
  • Each sub-centre to have one male and one female health worker

questions.text: Sexual gratification obtained by wearing the dress of opposite sex is seen in ______.
questions.solution:
Sexual gratification obtained by wearing a dress of opposite sex is known as Eonism.

Eonism / Transvestism is a type of sexual perversion, wherein the personality of a person is dominated by the desire to be identified and thought to be a member of the opposite sex. It is commonly found in males who obtain sexual gratification by wearing a female dress. Hormonal imbalance or genital abnormality is not seen in Eonism.

Types of Sexual perversions:

  • Eonism/Transvestism: Sexual gratification is achieved by wearing the dress of the opposite sex.
  • Fetishism: Gets sexual gratification by merely seeing or feeling female body parts, certain articles belonging to a woman, such as a sari, footwear, stockings, undergarments, hankies, hairpins, etc.
  • Masochism: Sexual gratification is obtained by being tortured by the sex partner. (opposite of Sadism)
  • Sadism: Sexual gratification is achieved by inducing pain in the sex partner.
  • Voyeurism/Peeping Tom or Scotophilia: Sexual gratification by secretly watching others getting undressed, taking a bath, or performing sexual intercourse, etc. (Option A)
  • Troilism: Gets sexual gratification by watching his own wife performing, sexual intercourse with another man.(Option D)
  • Nymphomaniac: A type of perversion of excessive sexual desire in a woman
  • Satyriasis: Excessive sexual desire, arousal, and drive in men.
  • Frotteurism: Gets sexual gratification by pressing/rubbing his genital part through the dresses worn, against the body parts of a female in front of him.(Option B)
  • Undinism: Gets sexual gratification by watching the act of passing urine or defecating by a woman.

questions.text: Liver synthesizes all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Immunoglobulins are not synthesized by the liver. They are produced by plasma cells.

Plasma proteins synthesized by the liver are:

  • Albumin
  • Coagulation/clotting factors
  • Acute-phase proteins
  • Steroid binding and other hormone-binding proteins

questions.text: An immunocompromised individual is diagnosed to have Pneumocystis jirovecii infection. Which of the following statements is false about this organism?

choices.text: Cyst wall stains black with methenamine silver stain
It grows readily on Sabouraud agar
Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is used for prophylaxis in HIV patients

questions.solution:
Pneumocystis jirovecii can not be cultured in vitro and the diagnosis depends on direct visualization of cysts and/or trophozoites in lower respiratory tract specimens.

P. jirovecii has three morphological forms:

  • Trophozoite - thin-walled, irregularly shaped
  • Precyst - an intermediate stage of the sexual phase
  • Cyst - thick-walled, spherical in shape. It contains intracystic bodies

Trophozoites can be demonstrated by Giemsa, toluidine blue, methenamine silver, and calcofluor white stains. The cyst wall stains black with methenamine silver stain.

 

Infection is transmitted by respiratory droplets. It is asymptomatic in immunocompetent individuals. In immunocompromised patients, it causes life-threatening pneumonia called pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP). PCP is one of the common opportunistic infections in AIDS. Patients with PCP generally present with fever and a non-productive cough with dyspnea. 

The diagnosis is made by highly specific staining of the cyst in the lung tissue or pulmonary secretions with methenamine silver, toluidine blue O, or Giemsa or by staining with a specific immunofluorescent antibody. The presence of organisms in bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) fluid is almost 100% sensitive and specific for PCP in patients with HIV infection. Perihilar diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates are classically seen on radiographs. Cysts and pneumothoraces are common chest radiographic findings.

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMZ) and pentamidine isothionate are the drugs of choice for the treatment of acute cases. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is also used for prophylaxis in HIV patients.

questions.text: A new drug has a volume of distribution of 12 L. It is excreted by first-order kinetics and has a half life of 10 hours. If given by continuous infusion, how long will it take for the drug to achieve 95% plasma steady state concentration?
questions.solution:
In first-order kinetics, a constant fraction of the drug is excreted in a given time. When given as a continuous infusion it reaches 95% steady state concentration in 4 half lives (10 x 4 = 40 hrs). 

The half-life (t1/2) is the time taken for the plasma concentration of the drug to be reduced by 50%. In first-order kinetics, the rate of elimination of the drug is directly proportional to the drug concentration. The rate of clearance remains constant in first-order kinetics.

questions.text: An 18-month-child with gonadal dysgenesis presents with a large abdominal mass. On resection, the gross appearance of the mass is as seen below. Which of the following tumors does the patient most likely have?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has nephroblastoma (Wilms tumor).

The history of a large abdominal mass in a young child and the resected gross specimen, which shows well-circumscribed tumor with multiple necrotic, hemorrhagic, and cystic changes seen in the upper pole of the kidney, is strongly suggestive of Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma). The history of gonadal dysgenesis aids the diagnosis of Wilms tumor, which is associated with Denys–Drash syndrome.

Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma): It is the most common primary renal tumor of childhood (peaks 2-5 years of age).

Other options

  • Renal cell carcinoma is a malignant tumor of adults.
  • Angiomyolipoma may rarely be seen in children.
  • Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid tumor of childhood arising from adrenal medulla; however, it is not associated with gonadal dysgenesis. 

Image: The histopathological image shows the characteristic triphasic components:

  1. Malignant small round (blue) cells (blastemal component).
  2. Tubular structures/rosettes (epithelial component).
  3. Loose pauci-cellular stroma with spindle cells (stromal component)

questions.text: A resident was inserting a central venous line through the femoral vein. He accidentally injured the structure medial to the femoral vein, within the femoral sheath. Which structure is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The lymphatic vessels lie medial to the femoral vein and are likely to be injured in this case.

Femoral sheath is the funnel-shaped prolongation of the fascia which contains femoral vessels. Anteriorly it is made of transversalis fascia and posteriorly it is made of fascia iliaca.

It is divided into three compartments:

  • The lateral compartment contains femoral artery
  • The intermediate compartment contains femoral vein
  • The medial compartment which is termed as femoral canal contains:
    • Lymphatic vessels
    • Areolar tissue
    • Lymph node of Cloquet. 

The empty space in the femoral canal allows distension of the adjacent femoral vein, so it can cope with increased venous return, or increased intra-abdominal pressure.

questions.text: Regarding palatoprints, all are true except?

choices.text: Palatal rugae are unique to each person
Palatoprints are located in posterior part of palate
Palatoprints do not change during growth

questions.solution:
Anterior part of the palate has rough raised ridges known as Palatoprints or palatal rugae.

Palatal rugae are irregular, asymmetric ridges of mucous membranes on the palate which are unique to each person and hence used as a method of identification.

Once formed, they do not undergo any changes during growth, remaining in the same position throughout a person's entire life.

The study of palatal rugae to establish identity is known as Rugoscopy/ Palatoscopy/ Palatoprints.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccine vials can be used based on the vaccine vial monitor (VVM) color changes shown?
questions.solution:
From the above image, only vials 1 and 2 can be used as the inner squares of the VVMs are lighter than the outer circles.

Vial 3 has crossed the discard point as the inner square and outer circle are the same color and thus cannot be used. Vial 4 cannot be used as the VVM shows a darker inner square compared to the outer circle.

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: An intellectually challenged teenager was diagnosed with a trinucleotide repeat mutation disease. On examination, his IQ is 49. He has a long face with a large mandible, everted large ears, a high-arched palate, and large testicles. What is the most likely nucleotide repeat sequence in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette is suggestive of fragile X syndrome. The specific trinucleotide repeat sequence in fragile X syndrome is CGG.

Fragile X syndrome is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability after Down's syndrome. It is due to the mutation in the familial mental retardation 1 gene (FMR1) located on the long arm of the X chromosome. 

It is associated with the phenomenon of anticipation, where the disease phenotype worsens over generations within a family. The affected males are intellectually disabled, with an IQ in the range of 20 to 60. Neuropsychiatric features include aggressive behavior, autism spectrum disorder, epilepsy, and anxiety/hyperactivity disorders.

The characteristic phenotypic features include the following:

  • Long face with a large mandible
  • Large everted ears
  • Macro-orchidism (large testicles)
  • Hyperextensible joints
  • High arched palate
  • Mitral valve prolapse

Other options:

Option A: CAG is the trinucleotide repeat sequence present in Huntington’s disease, spinocerebellar ataxia 1,2,3,6,7 and spinobulbar muscular atrophy.

Option B: CTG is the trinucleotide repeat sequence present in myotonic dystrophy.

Option D: GAA is the trinucleotide repeat sequence present in Friedreich ataxia.

questions.text: Which of the following antiarrhythmic drugs is contraindicated in a patient with interstitial lung disease?
questions.solution:
Amiodarone is contraindicated in a patient with interstitial lung disease.

The most serious adverse effect during chronic amiodarone therapy is pulmonary fibrosis, which can be rapidly progressive and fatal. Underlying lung disease, doses of 400 mg/day or more, and recent pulmonary insults such as pneumonia appear to be risk factors for this condition.

Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic drug.

The side effects of amiodarone include:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis
  • Hypotension, depressed ventricular function
  • Torsades de pointes
  • Corneal microdeposits
  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Neuropathies
  • Photosensitivity
  • Thyroid dysfunction

questions.text: Which of the following solutions is recommended as the diluent for the BCG vaccine ?
questions.solution:
Normal saline is recommended as the diluent for the BCG vaccine as distilled water is an irritant.

 BCG (Bacillus Calmette-Guérin) vaccine:

  • The WHO recommends Danish 1331 strain for BCG vaccine production.
  • Normal saline is recommended as the diluent for the BCG vaccine as distilled water is an irritant.
  • The dose administered is 0.1ml containing 0.1mg.
  • It is administered intradermally by using 26 gauge tuberculin syringe on the left deltoid.

RTS,S/AS01 is effective against P. Falciparum. Phase 3 trial of this vaccine has already been completed. There is a positive scientific opinion about its risk benefit balance and a phase 4 trial is under evaluation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient was brought to the emergency room with complaints of severe headache, sweating, and palpitations. She gives a history of the consumption of red wine. She was on selegiline for treatment of Parkinsonism. On examination, her BP is 200/110mmHg. Which of the following drugs is preferred for treating hypertension in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cheese reaction and phentolamine is the preferred drug for treating hypertension in this patient.

Tyramine is a sympathomimetic amine. In patients who are on monoamine oxidase inhibitors (selegiline), when they consume tyramine-rich foods like cheese, aged meat, red wine, fish, etc, the amine does not undergo degradation along the intestinal walls and liver and reaches the circulations. These amines release large amounts of catecholamines in the adrenergic nerve endings.

Therefore the patients will present with hypertension, agitation, diaphoresis, tachycardia, muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, etc. This will be followed by hypotension and coma.

Patients should be managed symptomatically by cooling, use of antipyretics, fluid administration, etc. This hypertensive crisis is treated with short-acting drugs like phentolamine.

Phentolamine is a non-selective alpha antagonist that opposes the alpha receptor-mediated vasoconstriction of sympathomimetics. It is also used in:

  • clonidine withdrawal
  • short-term control of hypertension in pheochromocytoma
  • limiting the duration of soft tissue anesthesia.

Other options:

Option A: Phenoxybenzamine is also a non-selective alpha antagonist but has irreversible action. We need short-acting drugs to manage hypertension in cheese reaction because long-acting drugs will worsen the hypotensive phase that follows hypertensive crisis. It is used in the treatment of pheochromocytoma.

Option C: Prazosin is a selective alpha-1 blocker. Catecholamines have an action on both alpha 1 and alpha 2 receptors that result in vasoconstriction. Another major problem with prazosin is marked postural hypotension and syncope following the first dose (first dose effect). So, using phentolamine is better as it is a non-selective alpha-receptor antagonist. Prazosin has been used in the treatment of hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia.

Option D: Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker. It can worsen hypertensive crisis by unopposed alpha stimulation. It is used in various conditions like essential hypertension, pheochromocytoma, myocardial infarction, cardiac arrhythmias, etc.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient with congestive cardiac failure develops sudden onset skin rashes, tongue swelling, and stridor. He had taken a newly prescribed tablet today morning. Which medication is most likely to have caused this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of drug-induced angioedema. The drug most likely to have caused this is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor like captopril. 

ACE inhibitors can cause angioedema in a small group which presents as swelling of the throat, mouth, tongue, and glottis. It is usually self-limiting once the drug is discontinued. Glucocorticoids, antihistamines, or epinephrine can be given if required. 

Other adverse effects include hypotension, dry cough, hyperkalemia, and skin rashes. In patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis, it can precipitate acute renal failure.  A rarer complication is visceral angioedema marked by vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. It is a known teratogen and needs to be replaced with other drugs during pregnancy/ birth control measures should be advised.

These drugs are inhibitors of the renin-angiotensin system and are commonly used in hypertension, left ventricular systolic dysfunction, and acute myocardial infarction. 

Other options:

Option A: Propranolol is a nonselective beta-receptor antagonist. Side effects include bronchospasm, depression, and insomnia. It is not recommended for diabetics as it can mask hypoglycemic symptoms.

Option C: Hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic can cause hypotension, hypokalemia, and hyponatremia.

Option D: Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist which can cause dry mouth, sedation, and sexual dysfunction.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient is told about the benefits and complications of hysterectomy and she agrees to the procedure. What kind of consent is this?
questions.solution:
This kind of consent is informed consent since the patient has been made aware of the benefits and complications and has agreed to the procedure.

Informed consent is one given by the patient after understanding the nature of the condition, proposed treatment, outcomes of the recommended treatment, alternative options to treatment, and the risks and benefits involved. The patient can accept or reject the procedure. This is also called the rule of full disclosure. 

Consent refers to a voluntary agreement, compliance, or permission. It can be expressed or implied. 

Implied consent (option B) is that which is not written or expressly stated. It is implied that the patient is giving consent to examination in a general sense. For example, when a patient visits the hospital with an illness, it implies that he has given consent to a physical examination to find out the nature of his illness. Another example of implied consent is when a patient exposes his arm for injection. It is legally effective.

Expressed consent can be oral or written and refers to consent in which the terms are clearly stated in distinct and explicit language.

Opt out (Option C) refers to a patient's refusal of the procedure, test, or treatment. It is the physician's duty to disclose the risks or consequences of refusal adequately and appropriately to the patient.

Passive consent (Option D) is not commonly described. However, in regard to research, it refers to parents signing and returning a form if they do not want to allow their child to participate in research.

questions.text: A screening test was carried out among 114 people of which 15 had the disease. 22  people tested positive for the disease among which 14 had the disease. What is the sensitivity of the test?
questions.solution:
In this scenario:

 

Disease +

Disease -

Total

Test +

14 (TP)

8 (FP)

22

Test -

1 (FN)

91 (TN)

92

Total

15

99

114

[TP- True positive, TN- True Negative, FP- False positive, FN- Flase Negative]

Sensitivity is given as TP/(TP + FN) x 100. Thus, sensitivity is 93.3%.

Related Pearl: Evaluation of diagnostic tests

Different ways of asking the following parameters:

Sensitivity (True positive rate) 

  • Percentage of diseased individuals who are correctly identified (as diseased).
  • Proportion of all people with the disease who test positive.
  • Probability that when the disease is present, the test is positive.

Specificity (True negative rate) 

  • Percentage of healthy individuals who are correctly identified (as healthy).
  • Proportion of all people without the disease who test negative.
  • Probability that when the disease is absent, the test is negative.

Positive predictive value 

  • Probability that a person who has a positive test result actually has the disease.
  • If the test is positive, what is the probability that the patient has the disease?

Negative predictive value 

  • Probability that a person who has a negative test result actually does not have the disease.
  • If the test is negative, what is the probability that the patient does not have the disease?

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ Accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Speciifity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: How much is the inulin clearance?
questions.solution:
Inulin clearance is equal to 125 ml/ min. Since it is used for the measurement of GFR, inulin clearance will be equal to GFR, i.e 125 ml/min

Renal clearance is the volume of plasma completely cleared of a substance by the kidneys per unit time. 

A higher renal clearance suggests the substance may be cleared almost completely in one pass through the kidneys while a low value describes a substance that may not be eliminated by the kidneys at all.

Clearance refers to the volume of plasma that would be necessary to supply the amount of substance excreted in the urine per unit of time. Stated mathematically,

Cx. Px = Ux. V

where Cx is the clearance rate of a substance x

Px is the plasma concentration of x

Ux is the urine concentration of that x

V is the urine flow rate

Rearranging this equation, clearance can be expressed as

questions.text: The X-Ray of a middle aged man showed multiple lytic lesions following which a urine examination was done. The sample revealed Bence Jones proteins. Which is the most common immunoglobulin associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario consisting of multiple lytic bony lesions and Bence Jones proteins indicates multiple myeloma.  Most myelomas are associated with more than 3 g/dL of serum Ig and/or more than 6 mg/dL of urine Bence Jones protein. The most common monoclonal Immunoglobulin (M protein) is IgG followed by IgA.

Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell neoplasm commonly associated with lytic bone lesions, hypercalcemia, renal failure, and acquired immune abnormalities.

Multiple myeloma usually presents as destructive plasma cell tumors involving the axial skeleton. The bones most commonly affected in descending order of frequency are the vertebral column, ribs, skull, pelvis, femur, clavicle, and scapula. 

Morphology:

  • Malignant plasma cells have a perinuclear clearing due to a prominent golgi apparatus and an eccentrically placed nucleus.
  • Relatively normal-appearing plasma cells, plasmablasts with vesicular nuclear chromatin and a prominent single nucleolus, or bizarre, multinucleated cells may predominate.
  • Other cytologic variants include flame cells, Mott cells.
  • Flame cells have fiery red cytoplasm, Mott cells contain multiple grapelike cytoplasmic droplets, a variety of other inclusions, including fibrils, crystalline rods, and globules. The globular inclusions are referred to as Russell bodies (if cytoplasmic) or Dutcher bodies (if nuclear).
  • Rouleaux formation is characteristic but not specific. High levels of M protein in the blood causes red cells to stick to one another in linear arrays in smears leading to rouleaux formation.

Image showing peripheral smear of multiple myeloma:

Poor prognostic factors for multiple myeloma:

  • Serum β2-microglobulin. It is the single most powerful predictor
  • Deletion of 17pITP53 sequences and the translocations t(14;16) and t(14;20)
  • Polyclonal serum Immunoglobulins
  • Elevated lactate dehydrogenase
  • High C-reactive protein
  • Increased plasma cell proliferative activity
  • High degree of bone marrow replacement
  • Presence of plasmablastic morphology
  • Elevated serum soluble receptor for IL6

The clinicopathologic diagnosis of multiple myeloma can be done based on the identification of clonal plasma cells in the marrow and the presence of CRAB criteria (hypercalcemia, renal dysfunction, anemia, and bone lesions).

Other options:

A) Ig A is not the most common immunoglobulin associated with the presence of Bence Jones proteins in the urine. While Ig A can be involved in some cases, Ig G is the most frequently observed immunoglobulin in this context.

B) Ig D is not commonly associated with the presence of Bence Jones proteins in the urine. Bence Jones proteins are typically composed of monoclonal immunoglobulin light chains, and Ig D is not commonly involved in plasma cell disorders such as multiple myeloma.

D) Ig M is not the most common immunoglobulin associated with the presence of Bence Jones proteins in the urine. While Ig M can be involved in certain plasma cell disorders, Ig G is the most frequently observed immunoglobulin associated with Bence Jones proteins.

Related Pearl: International Staging System (ISS) for multiple myeloma:

International Staging System (ISS) for multiple myeloma:

β2 microglobulin (mg/dL) and albumin (g/dL) level Stage Median survival months

β2M < 3.5

alb ≥3.5

 I 62

β2M < 3.5, alb < 3.5

or β2M = 3.5-5.5

 II 44
β2M > 5.5 III 29

ISS is the most widely used method of assesing prognosis in multiple myeloma.

questions.text: You are writing a paper about the growth and development of children. You are doubtful about a few points. Which of the following statements given below is not true?

choices.text: Head circumference should be measured within 24 hours after birth
Head circumference equals chest circumference at 1 year of age
A boys height at 2 and half years is half of his adult height
A girls height at 2 years is half of her adult height

questions.solution:
Head circumference should not be measured within 24 hours because the head is subjected to molding during delivery, which makes the measurements unreliable.

The maximum circumference of the head from the occipital protuberance to the supraorbital ridges on the forehead is recorded using the cross-tape method.

Age Head circumference
At birth 33 to 35cm
3 m 40 cm
6 m 43 cm
1 year 46 cm
2 years 48 cm
3 years 49 cm
4 years 50 cm
12 years 52 cm (adult size)
  • Head circumference increases by the following:
    • 2 cm/month in first 3 months
    • 1 cm/month in next 3 months
    • 0.5 cm/month in next 6 months

Head circumference is more than chest circumference by 2.5 cm at birth.

  • At birth: Head circumference > Chest circumference
  • At 9-12 months: Head circumference = Chest circumference
  • After 1 year: Head circumference < Chest circumference

Interesting fact!

A boy's height at 2 and half years is half of his adult height and a girl's height at 2 years is half of her adult height.

To roughly predict adult height, use the formula:

  • Adult height = height at 2.5 years for boys (or 2 years for girls) X 2

According to WHO growth charts, the height-for-age for most of the children lies between 70-90 cm during these periods. The double of it, i.e. 140-180 cm is the average height that most of us achieve as adults.

questions.text: A child with mental retardation, blindness, and muscle weakness was investigated and was found to be deficient for the Hexosaminidase-A enzyme. She is most likely suffering from ____.
questions.solution:
Tay-Sachs disease is due to the deficiency of the enzyme Hexosaminidase A which degrades GM2 gangliosides.

Clinical features of Tay-Sachs disease are :

  • Loss of motor skills
  • Seizures
  • Hyperacusis
  • Macrocephaly
  • Macular cherry-red spots
  • Neurodegeneration
  • Blindness
  • Muscular weakness

Related Pearl: Important causes of cherry-red spots

  • Commotio retinae
  • Central retinal and cilioretinal artery occlusion
  • Metabolic storage diseases
    • GM1 gangliosidosis
    • Mucolipidosis type I (sialidosis)
    • GM2 gangliosidosis (Tay-Sachs disease and Sandhoff disease)
    • Farber disease
    • Niemann–Pick disease
  • Retinotoxicity due to specific agents, including quinine, dapsone, gentamicin, carbon monoxide, and methanol

questions.text: While working as a resident in a hospital, you are asked by the consultant to prescribe a certain proton-pump inhibitor (PPI). It should be given only orally once daily before breakfast, even though it has a half-life of no more than 3 hours. What is the rationale behind this once-daily dosing?

choices.text: The drug can inhibit all gastric pumps.
The drug irreversibly inactivates the pump molecule.
The drug is gradually released irrespective of its formulation.
The drug suppresses basal but not stimulated acid production.

questions.solution:
The rationale behind the once-daily dosing is that the drug irreversibly inactivates the pump molecule.

Proton-pump inhibitors (PPIs) are prodrugs that are activated only after undergoing an acid-catalyzed cleavage in the canaliculi of the parietal cells of the stomach.

On administration, they are absorbed in the proximal small bowel and eventually, block the H+/K+ ATPase enzyme, the "proton pump" in the parietal cells of the stomach. The secretion of protons by an activated H+/K+- ATPase (proton pump) in the parietal cells into the gastric lumen is the final step involved in the production of gastric acid and inhibition of this enzyme prevents acid secretion into the stomach.

Once PPIs irreversibly inactivate the H+K+-ATPase pump, acid secretion resumes only after new pump molecules are synthesized and inserted into the luminal membrane. This leads to prolonged suppression of acid secretion for up to 24-48 hours, despite having a shorter plasma half-life of only 30 minutes to 3 hours.

In most individuals, once-daily dosing is enough to achieve effective acid inhibition. If necessary, a second dose can be given before an evening meal.

The number of H+K+-ATPase pump molecules increases after fasting and food decreases the oral bioavailability of the drug. Hence, PPIs are given around 30 minutes before the first meal of the day.

PPIs cannot inhibit all gastric acid pumps with oral dosing because not all pumps are active during the short half-life of the PPI in the blood. 

PPIs cause maximum suppression of gastric acid. They reduce the daily production of both basal and stimulated acid secretion by 85–90%. 

There are available in the form of delayed-release tablets, capsules, and oral suspension packets and for immediate acid suppression, there are intravenous formulations for PPIs like lansoprazole, pantoprazole, and esomeprazole. Therefore, the release of the drug depends upon the drug formulation.

questions.text: Ubiquitin is a key molecule in protein degradation. Ubiquitinated proteins are degraded by ______
questions.solution:
Ubiquitination is an enzymatic, post-translational modification involving the covalent binding of a small 76–amino acid protein, ubiquitin, to the proteins. This process most commonly binds the last amino acid of ubiquitin (glycine 76) to a lysine residue on the substrate.

  • Ubiquitination usually marks denatured or misfolded proteins for degradation by the proteasome.
  • Polymeric proteasome complex is a cylinder-like structure containing multiple, different protease activities, into which the poly-ubiquitinated molecules are unfolded and funnelled, each with its active site pointed at the hollow core.
  • Proteasomes digest proteins into small (6 to 12 amino acids) fragments that can subsequently be degraded to their constituent amino acids and recycled.
  • Ubiquitination of proteins may also alter their cellular location, affect their activity, and promote or prevent protein interactions.

Clinical importance: Proteasome inhibitor - bortezomib is used in multiple myeloma and hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: A young patient presents to the outpatient department with complaints of chronic scaly plaques over the extensor surface associated with pruritus. On examination, the patient's nails demonstrate subungual hyperkeratosis and distal onycholysis as shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is psoriasis. The pruritic scaly lesions, onycholysis, and subungual hyperkeratosis are nail findings seen in patients with psoriasis.

Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the skin with systemic manifestations. Patients commonly present with red, scaly plaques over the extensor surfaces and the scalp, associated with pruritus.

Nail findings are commonly seen across all types of psoriasis. Patients present with pits, ridges, and grooves of the nail plate. In the case of nail bed involvement subungual oil drops, subungual hyperkeratosis, and distal onycholysis can be seen.

Other options:

Option A - Lichen planus is an inflammatory disorder affecting the skin and mucosal membranes. Nail involvement includes exaggeration of the longitudinal lines and linear depression. This is due to nail plate thinning. If the nail bed is involved, it can result in hyperpigmentation, subungual hyperkeratosis, and onycholysis. In some cases, pterygium unguis can be seen due to adhesion between the dorsal nail fold and the nail bed.

Option C - Atopic dermatitis presents with itchy erythematous papules/papulo-vesicles in flexural regions. Patients usually have a history of other autoimmune diseases.

Option D - Alopecia areata is a condition that results in non-scarring hair loss. It can cause fine stippled pitting of the nails, roughening of the nail plate (trachyonychia), or atrophic dystrophy.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

questions.text: Which of the following stains is used for the detection of hemosiderin deposits?
questions.solution:
Perl's Prussian blue stain is used to detect hemosiderin deposits.

Hemosiderin is a hemoglobin-derived granular pigment that is golden-yellow to brown. It accumulates in the tissues when there is a local or systemic excess of iron.

Iron is normally stored within cells in association with the protein apoferritin, forming ferritin micelles. Large aggregates of these micelles are hemosiderin deposits seen both in light and electron microscopy. 

Image 1: Hemosiderin deposits in tissue

Image 2: Prussian blue staining of hemosiderin

*Note: Iron dispersed in the cytoplasm is seen in electron microscopy as ferritin micelles.

questions.text: A 29-year-old presented with purple, pruritic plaques on the flexor aspect of the left forearm for 7 months. On examination, Koebner's phenomenon was elicited. A skin biopsy showed Civatte bodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario with symptoms of purple, itchy, plaque exhibiting Koebner's phenomenon is suggestive of lichen planus. It is characterized by the presence of Civatte bodies or colloid bodies.

The colloid body is a homogeneous, eosinophilic, rounded body resulting from the degeneration and death of keratinocytes, particularly in the lower layers of the epidermis. This structure is found in various lichenoid tissue reactions.

Lichen planus (LP) is an idiopathic inflammatory disease affecting the skin and mucous membrane. Microscopy will show :

  • Acanthosis of the epidermis.
  • Irregular thickening of the granular layer.
  • Hyperkeratosis.
  • Colloid (civatte) bodies due to degenerating basal epidermal cells. 
  • Sawtooth appearance of rete ridges.
  • Max Joseph spaces due to focal separation from the dermis.
  • Band‐like infiltrate of lymphocytes and histiocytes near the dermo-epidermal junction.

Patients present with pruritic, purple, polygonal, papules. The lesions have thin white lines on their surface known as Wickham’s striae (seen below). They are commonly seen on the volar aspect of the wrists, the lumbar region, and around the ankles.

The mucosal involvement is also seen. The commonest mucosal sites are buccal mucosa and tongue, rarely it can also be found on the anus and genitalia. 

Option A: Copper penny bodies are seen in chromoblastomycosis.

Option C: Donovan bodies are seen in granuloma inguinale.

Option D: Kamino bodies are eosinophilic globules seen in the epidermis or in the region of the dermal-epidermal junction in the spindle and epithelioid cell (Spitz) naevi.

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

Psoriasis

Psoriasis

Vitiligo

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

questions.text: An insured 35-year-old woman, who is working in a newspaper establishment, is undergoing a tubectomy procedure. According to the Employees State Insurance Act, she would receive the cash benefit under ____.
questions.solution:
Insured persons in the reproductive age group undergoing sterilization procedures such as tubectomy and vasectomy are offered cash benefit under the ESI Act as enhanced sickness benefit. 

The enhanced sickness benefit equal to full wage is payable to insured persons undergoing sterilization. 7 days for male workers, post-vasectomy, and 14 days for female workers, post-tubectomy.

Other options: 

Option B: Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.

Option C: Maternity Benefit – the benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman

Option D: Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

questions.text: Mixing biomedical waste with different constituents before disposal to reduce its toxicities is known as _______.
questions.solution:
Inertization is the process of mixing the biomedical waste with non-toxic substances to reduce the toxicity in the waste and to reduce the contamination of ground water.
It is most commonly used for incineration ash with high metal content

The typical composition of the mixture is

  • 65% pharmaceutical waste
  • 15% cement
  • 15% lime
  • Water

questions.text: Which of the following parameter is used in the calculation of the pearl index?
questions.solution:
The parameter used in the calculation of the pearl index is total accidental pregnancies.

Pearl Index:

  • The pearl index is defined as the number of failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

It can be calculated as follows.

  • The total accidental pregnancies must include all pregnancies irrespective of the outcome(live births, still-births or abortions).
  • The total months of exposure is obtained by deducting 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

questions.text: Insulin-stimulated glucose uptake takes place in all the following except ___________.
questions.solution:
Insulin stimulated glucose uptake take place in heart, skeletal muscle and adipose tissue through GLUT 4

In the liver, the transport of glucose is through GLUT 2, which is insulin independent.

GLUT-4 is present in skeletal muscle cells and cardiomyocytes.

Additionally,the glucose transporter responsible for insulin-mediated glucose uptake into adipocytes is also GLUT-4.

Glucose transporters, also referred to as GLUTs, are transport proteins in the cell membrane responsible for the transfer of glucose into the cells by facilitative diffusion. Facilitative diffusion involves the passage of molecules or ions through the cell membrane by them binding chemically to a carrier/ transport protein that is responsible for their movement across the cell membrane.

GLUT-4 is a transport protein present in adipocytes. When there is a rise in blood glucose level, insulin secreted by the pancreatic beta cells binds to its receptors on the plasma membrane of adipocytes. Upon binding of insulin to its receptor, activation of the receptor's tyrosine-kinase domain occurs. This activation starts a protein activation cascade leading to the translocation of GLUT4 to the plasma membrane.

Once translocation occurs and GLUT4 is inserted into the plasma membrane, facilitated diffusion of glucose down its concentration gradient into the cell occurs.

GLUT-2 is found in the liver, pancreatic β cell, small intestine, and kidney. Its function is the rapid uptake or release of glucose.

GLUT-5 is present in the small intestine and is involved in the absorption of fructose.

SGLT-1 is a sodium-dependent unidirectional transporter present in the small intestine and kidney that is involved in the active uptake of glucose against a concentration gradient.

questions.text:
Match the type of collagen with its associated disease entity.
Types of collagen Collagen defect disorders
1. Type I

A. Stickler syndrome
2. Type II B. Alport syndrome
3. Type III C. Ehler Danlos syndrome (vascular subtype)
4. Type IV D. Osteogenesis imperfecta
questions.solution:
The correctly matched type of collagen with its associated disease entity is 1-D, 2-A, 3-C, 4-B. 

Collagen is the most abundant protein and approximately 28 types have been isolated. The structure of collagen is a triple helix composed of 3 polypeptide chains having glycine residues at every third position.

Genetic defects in the various types of collagen found predominantly at specific sites lead to various diseases summarized in the table below.

Type of Collagen Distribution Defect
Type I

Noncartilaginous connective tissues, including bone, tendon, skin

 Osteogenesis imperfecta
Type II

Cartilage, vitreous humor

 Stickler syndrome
Type III

Extensible connective tissues, including skin, lung, and vascular system

Ehler Danos syndrome (Vascular sub-type)
Type IV  

Basement membranes

 Alport syndrome
Type VII  

Dermal-epidermal junction

 Epidermolysis bullosa aquisita

 

In osteogenesis imperfecta, there is a severe decrease in bone mass that makes bones brittle, associated with blue sclerae, dental abnormalities, progressive hearing loss, and positive family history.

Stickler syndrome is characterized by skeletal changes, orofacial abnormalities, and auditory abnormalities.

In Ehler Danlos syndrome ( vascular subtype ) there are features of classic EDS ( skin and joint involvement ) as well as severe muscular hypotonia after birth, progressive kyphoscoliosis, osteopenia, occasional rupture of the eye globe, and great arteries.

Alport syndrome is characterized by the presence of a genetically abnormal basement membrane giving rise to proteinuria and hematuria.

questions.text:
The required increase in caloric intake of a lactating mother in the first 6 months is __

PHC: Primary health care
questions.solution:
During the first six months of lactation, an increase of 600 Kcal/day is recommended, and from 7-12 months of lactation, an addition of 520 Kcal/day is recommended.

Pregnancy requires an additional 80,000 kcal during the last 20 weeks. This intake is not equally divided during pregnancy. It is divided as 0, ~340, and 350 kcal/day in the first, second, and third trimester, respectively. 

Pregnancy is a period where a mother will require additional nutritional requirements to support the healthy growth and development of the fetus. According to the recommended dietary allowances by the Indian council of medical research (ICMR):

13g/day - 7-12 months

Iodine 220μg/day  280μg/day

 

Other options:

Option C: The caloric intake per day should be increased to 340 Kcal/day for a woman in her second trimester.

questions.text: A 9-month-old boy presents with progressive pallor and abdominal distension. Red cell distribution width is normal.  The peripheral smear is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and peripheral blood smear showing target cells and aniso-poikilocytosis, along with the normal red cell distribution width(RDW), are suggestive of thalassemia.

Thalassemia is a hemoglobinopathy that arises due to deficient synthesis of the globin chains. Depending on the chain affected, it is classified into α-thalassemia and β-thalassemia.

β-Thalassemia arises due to the deficient synthesis of β-chains. Normal adult RBCs have HbA, along with HbA2 and fetal haemoglobin (HbF) in small amounts. There is a deficit in the synthesis of HbA with an elevation of HbA2 and HbF levels in β-thalassemia. 

α-Thalassemia is caused by deficient synthesis of α-chains. It can also present as an α-thalassemia trait, with trivial hematologic abnormalities. Excess of β- and γ-globin chains form Bart hemoglobin (γ4) in fetal life and HbH (β4) after birth. Severe deficiency leads to hydrops fetalis.

Ineffective erythropoiesis leads to bone marrow hyperplasia and extramedullary hematopoiesis, which can involve the liver, spleen, and lymph nodes. In β-thalassemia major, anemia manifests 6 to 9 months after birth. HbF levels are markedly elevated. The presence of bony anomalies such as frontal bossing, prominent facial bones, and dental malocclusion is typical.

The image below shows thalassemic facies (frontal bossing and maxillary hyperplasia) in a child with thalassemia major. 

Laboratory findings: Infants with severe β-thalassemia diseases experience increasing anemia following the newborn stage. The RBCs exhibit microcytosis, hypochromia, and target cells. Usually observed are nucleated RBCs, a distinct anisopoikilocytosis, and relative reticulocytopenia. Without transfusions, the Hb level frequently drops to 6 g/dL in a gradual manner.

The RDW shows the size difference in the red blood cells. Low RDW means all the red blood cells are small and uniform in size, while a large RDW means that the cells vary in size. It is normal in case of thalassemia as all cells are uniformly small in size. It increases in iron deficiency anaemia because of presence of small and normal sized RBCs.

High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) confirms the diagnosis of thalassemia. It shows the absence of HbA and high levels of HbF.

Other options:

Option A: Glossitis, stomatitis, darkening of the skin on the knuckles and terminal phalanges, and enlargement of the liver and spleen are characteristics of megaloblastic anemia. Peripheral smear in megaloblastic anemia is characterized by macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils (shown below).

Option B: Iron deficiency anemia has high RDW. Peripheral smear shows microcytic hypochromic anemia along with target cells.

Option D: Megaloblastic anemia has a particular subtype called pernicious anemia. It is caused by insufficient vitamin B12 absorption through the gastrointestinal pathway, leading to vitamin B12 insufficiency. Macro-ovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils are frequent observations in the peripheral smear associated with megaloblastic anemia. Neutrophil hypersegmentation is an early symptom of the disease and typically occurs beyond 3 to 5 lobes.

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

questions.text: A researcher who was studying on Plasmodium species decided to visit the malaria-endemic place in Odisha after 2 days to do his clinical study for 5 weeks.  Which of the following drugs need to be taken as prophylaxis before visiting the malaria-endemic place?
questions.solution:
Doxycycline drug needs to be taken as prophylaxis by the researcher before going to malaria-endemic places.

Chemoprophylaxis in travelers:

  • If the duration of travel is less than 6 weeks then doxycycline 100mg once a day can be started 2 days before travel and continued at least 4 weeks after travel.
  • If the duration of travel is more than 6 weeks then mefloquine 250mg once a week can be started 2 weeks before travel and continued at least 4 weeks after travel.

Related Pearl: National Strategic Plan for Malaria Elimination 2017 - 2022

  • The National Strategic Plan (NSP) for Malaria Elimination (2017-22) was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare under NVBDCP, which is based on the National Framework for Malaria Elimination (2016 – 2030).
  • The NSP focuses mainly on the districts which function as the operational units.

Accordingly all the districts are classified into the following four categories

Category of districts Definition
Category 0: Prevention of re-establishment phase  Includes all districts in which no incidence of malaria was reported in last three years.
Category 1: Elimination phase  District in which annual parasite incidence (API), is less than one per 1000 population.
Category 2: Pre elimination phase  Districts with API in between one and two per 1000 population.
Category 3: Intensified control phase  Districts having API more than two.

The above classification is more operational than the classification mentioned in the NFME which is state focussed.

The goals of NSP strategy are phased elimination of malaria in India. The National Framework for Malaria Elimination (NFME) in India has set 2030 as goal for eliminating malaria, and the goals of NSP in consonance with overall goals.

The goals of NSP 2017 – 2022 are:

  • Eliminate malaria in category 1 (API < 1) districts by 2020, and category 2 (API 1 - 2) districts by 2022.
  • Reduce transmission in category 3 districts to stabilize API at less than 1 by 2022
