questions.text:
In an urban area in the state of Madhya Pradesh, a primigravida goes for institutional delivery after being motivated by an ASHA worker. What are the benefits they will receive (in terms of money in rupees) under the Janani Suraksha Yojana?

ASHA- Accredited social health activist
questions.solution:
According to Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) scheme, the mother will receive 1000 rupees and the ASHA worker will receive 400 rupees.

Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) is a program under the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM), whose aim is to reduce maternal mortality by encouraging delivery in government health facilities. Under the scheme, a financial incentive is also provided for giving birth in a government health facility. 

The Accredited Social Health Activist (ASHA) is the link between pregnant women and health institutions. She is responsible for making institutional antenatal and postnatal care available. 

States are divided into low-performing and high-performing on the basis of institutional delivery rate. (The 10 low-performing states (LPS) with a low institutional delivery rate are Uttar Pradesh, Uttarakhand, Madhya Pradesh, Jharkhand, Bihar, Rajasthan, Chattisgarh, Odisha, Assam, and Jammu & Kashmir. All the other states are high-performing states) (HPS).

The incentives under JSY are as follows:

Category  Rural area Urban area
LPS

Mother package: 1400/-
ASHA's package:600/-
Total:2000/-

 Mother package: 1000/-
ASHA's package:400/-
Total:1400/-
HPS Mother package: 700/-
ASHA's package:600/-
Total:1300/-		 Mother package: 600/-
ASHA's package:400/-
Total:1000/-

Under this scheme, the cost of cesarean section and management of obstetric complications is also subsidized, up to Rs 1500 per delivery to the government institutions, where government specialists are not present.

questions.text: Given below is an instrument which is used to measure air humidity. Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The instrument seen in the image is a Sling Psychrometer, It is used to measure the humidity/ moisture content in the air.

Sling Psychrometer has 2 mercury thermometers (wet and dry) in it. The wet bulb is moistened first with distilled water and the instrument is whirled/rotated standing with the back to the sun. The reading is noted twice.

Later the dry bulb is taken up for the reading and the relative air humidity is obtained by use of suitable tables and charts.

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

  • A number of thermometers which employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.
  • These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.
  • The instruments used to measure air temperature are:
    • Dry bulb thermometers:
      • These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level
    • Wet bulb thermometers
      • These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.
    • Maximum thermometer
      • This is a mercury thermometer which has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb
    • Minimum thermometer
      • The liquid in this thermometer is spirit which has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it
    • Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer
      • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
      • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
      • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available
  • Globe thermometer:
    • It is used for the direct measurement of mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
    • It has a hollow metal bulb (6 inches diameter) which has a matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
    • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.
  • Kata thermometers:
    • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
    • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
    • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: A health care worker has been found to be seropositive for HBsAg, HBeAg, and Anti-HBc: IgM, indicating an acute HBV infection with high infectivity. Liver biopsy in such cases is likely to show all of the following, except________.
questions.solution:
Ground-glass hepatocytes are not seen in acute hepatitis.

“Ground-glass” hepatocytes—cells with endoplasmic reticulum swollen by HBsAg—is a diagnostic hallmark in chronic hepatitis B.

The below image shows ground glass hepatocytes.

Related Pearl: Acute Hepatitis vs. Chronic Hepatitis

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought with complaints of persistent fever, and cough for 3 weeks. The child's mother is a known case of tuberculosis and is on treatment. As per the National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme guidelines, what should be the next step in management?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the child is exposed to tuberculosis and has symptoms suggestive of tuberculosis. Therefore the next step in management is to do sputum CBNAAT (Cartridge Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test). CBNAAT is the investigation of choice.

Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (NAAT) provides an accurate and rapid diagnosis of TB by detecting Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Rifampicin (Rif) resistance-conferring mutations, in sputum specimens as well as a specimen from extra-pulmonary sites. CBNAAT is recommended for diagnosis of DR-TB in presumptive DR-TB patients and TB preferentially in the key population such as children, PLHIV, Extra-pulmonary TB, and in smear-negative TB as per the diagnostic algorithm. 

Sputum smear microscopy(Option C) is done if CBNAAT facilities are not available. Chest X-ray (Option B) and Mantoux test or tuberculin skin test (Option D) are done if MTB is not detected or sputum is not available.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic algorithm for Pulmonary TB – National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) 2020 Guidelines

A presumptive pulmonary TB patient should undergo both Sputum examination and Chest X-ray.

If sputum and CXR is negative, CB NAAT should be done when the clinical suspicion is high:

As is inferred from the above table, irrespective of chest X ray findings, CB-NAAT is done in all cases where sputum examination is negative for diagnosis.

CB-NAAT is also performed in all microbiologically confirmed and notified cases of TB for drug susceptibility testing.

questions.text: A patient with lymphatic filarisis is being managed as shown in the image below. What is the level of prevention done here?
questions.solution:
The image shows an established case of chronic lymphatic filariasis, where hygiene is being maintained to prevent further disability by secondary bacterial infection. Disability limitation is a mode of intervention in tertiary prevention.

Other options:

Option A: Health promotion is a mode of intervention in primary prevention, and is the process of enabling people to increase control over, and improve health. Health promotion may be achieved through health education, environmental modification, nutritional interventions or lifestyle changes.

Option C: Primary prevention is a level of prevention which is defined as action taken prior to the onset of a disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur. It is accomplished by measures designed to promote general health and well-being.

Option D: Specific protection is a mode of intervention in primary prevention which aims at limiting the number of cases of a particular disease. This includes immunization, use of specific nutrients, chemoprophylaxis, accident protection, and avoidance of allergens.

Related Pearl: Levels of Prevention

Soften the impact of long-term disease and disability, minimize suffering

questions.text: A patient presented with an unknown fungal infection. Histological examination of the lesion shows the presence of round, irregular, dark brown, yeast-like bodies with septae. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Histological examination of the lesion showing round, irregular, dark brown, yeast-like bodies with septae is suggestive of sclerotic bodies. So the possible diagnosis is chromoblastomycosis.

Chromoblastomycosis is a subcutaneous infection caused by fungi belonging to the genera fonsecaea. It is more commonly seen in tropical areas among agricultural workers and woodcutters who walk barefoot. Traumatic implantation is the mode of infection.

Patients present with warty cauliflower-like cutaneous nodules on the feet and lower legs. The disease generally remains localized with slow peripheral extension. Lymphatic spread can occur.

Diagnosis can be established by demonstration of these sclerotic bodies or medlar bodies and by culture on Sabouraud agar. It appears as sclerotic bodies on histopathology examination and copper penny bodies on KOH mount.

The image below shows sclerotic bodies seen in chromoblastomycosis.

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man has come with complaints of hair loss. Examination findings are given below. The most likely diagnosis in this man is?
questions.solution:
The image above shows circumscribed, hairless, smooth patch. Short, easily extractable broken hairs, known as exclamation mark hairs, are seen at the margins of the bald patch. This is characteristic of alopecia areata.

It is characterized by a circumscribed, smooth patch of hair loss. Exclamation mark hairs are often seen at the margins of the bald patches during active phases of the disease. Follicular orifices may appear as yellow dots on dermoscopy.

Alopecia areata is a chronic, inflammatory, autoimmune disease that causes non-scarring hair loss.

Other options: 

Option A: Tinea capitis (as shown in the images below): The appearance may vary from dull grey, broken‐off hairs with a little scaling to a severe, painful, inflammatory mass covering the entire scalp. Predominantly seen in children, however, adults can also be affected due to infection by T.tonsurans. 

Option B: Kerion (T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes) is a severe inflammatory type that presents with an inflammatory mass with thick crusting and matting of hair with pus and sinus formation.

Option D: Trichotillomania (as shown in the image below) is a psychiatric disorder characterized by com­pulsive hair pulling. There is increased tension prior to the hair-pulling and a relief of tension or gratification after the hair-pulling. It presents as an area of patchy hair loss, often in a bizarre pattern. The hairs are often twisted and broken at various distances from the scalp or may be present as uniform, coarse stubble. The scalp skin appears normal.

questions.text: You were posted as a medical officer in a Kala-azar endemic area. There was a rise in the number of insects shown in the given image below. Identify the insect:
questions.solution:
The image given is that of a sandfly (Phlebotomus), which is the vector for Kala-azar.

Sandflies are generally small insects, light or dark brown in color. They are smaller than mosquitoes. Their body and wings are densely clothed with hair. Their wings are up-right and lanceolate in shape and their legs are longer compared with the size of the body. They hop about and do not fly much. The species of sandfly responsible for transmitting the disease kala-azar is Phlebotomus argentipes. 

Kala-azar or visceral leishmaniasis is a protozoal infection mainly affecting the reticuloendothelial system. It is caused by various species of the genus Leishmania. It can present as visceral leishmaniasis, cutaneous leishmaniasis, ad mucosal leishmaniasis. Clinical features of the visceral form include moderate to high-grade fever with chills and rigors, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. 

The gold standard test for the diagnosis is the demonstration of amastigotes in the smears of tissue aspirates. Another commonly used test is the detection of antibodies to a recombinant antigen called rK39 by a rapid immunochromatographic test. In immunocompromised individuals, parasites can be isolated from the buffy coat. Amphotericin B is the first-line drug used in India. 

Other diseases transmitted by sandflies include sandfly fever and oriental sore.

For the reduction of sandflies, a  single application of DDT (dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane) or lindane has been found effective. 

Other options:

Option A: Tsetse flies or glossinae are the blood-sucking flies that resemble the common houseflies. They are yellow or dark-brown in color. When folded, their wings overlap each other like the blade of a scissor. They have a non-retractile proboscis which is rigid and adapted for piercing the skin and sucking the blood. They are vectors for trypanosomiasis or sleeping sickness and are only found in regions in Africa.

 

Option C- Rat flea is the vector for plague and typhus. They are wingless, their head is conical in shape, and is directly attached to the thorax without a neck. The head has piercing mouth parts that are conspicuous and project downward for sucking blood. They have 3 pairs of legs attached to the thorax. 

Option D: Black flies are small robust flies. They are black short stout legs, large broad wings, and a short proboscis to suck blood. They are the vectors of onchocerciasis in Africa, Mexico, Central, and South America.

Related Pearl: Sandfly

  • They are also referred to as Phlebotomus.
  • They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), oriental sore, sandfly fever and oraya fever.
  • They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.
  • They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during night (nocturnal pests).
  • They do not fly for more than 50 yards
  • They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.

Related Pearl: Arthropod-borne Diseases

Mosquito Malaria, filaria, Japanese encephalitis, dengue, West Nile fever, yellow fever, etc.
Housefly Typhoid, paratyphoid fever, diarrhea, dysentery, cholera, gastroenteritis, amoebiasis, helminthic infestations, poliomyelitis, conjunctivitis, trachoma, anthrax, yaws, etc.
Sandfly (Phlebotomus) Kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), oriental sore, sandfly fever, oraya fever.
Tsetse fly Sleeping sickness (African trypanosomiasis)
Louse Epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, pediculosis
Rat flea Bubonic plague, endemic typhus (murine typhus), hymenolepis diminuta.
Blackfly (Simulum) Onchocerciasis
Reduviid bug (Kissing bug/Triatominae) Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis)
Hard tick Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, Kyasanur forest disease, tularemia, tick paralysis, human babesiosis, Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (RMSF)
Soft tick Relapsing fever
Ixodes tick Lyme disease, babesiosis and anaplasmosis.
Trombiculid mite Scrub typhus
House mouse mite Rickettsial pox
Itch mite Scabies
Cyclops Guinea worm disease, fish tapeworm
Cockroaches Enteric pathogens
Sand flea (Tunga penetrans, jigger or chigoe flea) Tungiasis, ulcers in feet/nails.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about DNA polymerase I?

choices.text: It is involved in the creation of okazaki fragments.
It is the primary enzyme of DNA synthesis.

questions.solution:
DNA polymerase I (pol I) is found in prokaryotes.

The prokaryotic polymerases are DNA polymerases I, II, and III.

DNA polymerase I recognize a “nick” or break in the phosphate backbone, and then removes each RNA primer and fills the gaps with DNA. It has DNA repair activity.

DNA polymerase II: DNA proofreading and repair.

DNA polymerase III: The primary enzyme for the synthesis of the leading strand of DNA. 

DNA polymerase δ synthesizes Okazaki fragments which are short, newly synthesized DNA fragments that are formed on the lagging template strand during DNA replication. They are complementary to the lagging template strand.

Primase synthesizes RNA primers to start the replication.

Related Pearl: Enzymes Involved in DNA Replication

Prokaryotic DNA replication enzymes and their function:

Enzyme Function
DNA Polymerase I (Pol I) Gap filling following DNA replication, repair, and recombination
DNA polymerase II (Pol II) DNA proofreading and repair
DNA polymerase III (Pol III)

Processive, leading strand synthesis, DNA proofreading
DnaG

Primase 
Helicase ATP-driven processive unwinding of DNA.
Primase Initiates synthesis of RNA primers.
Topoisomerase Relieve torsional strain that results from helicase-induced unwinding.
Single-strand binding proteins (SSBs) Prevents premature reannealing of dsDNA.
DNA ligase Seals the single strand nick between the nascent chain and Okazaki fragments on lagging strand.

 

Eukaryotic DNA polymerases:

Eukaryotic DNA Polymerases Functions Proofreading
α  Primase (initiates DNA synthesis) -
β DNA repair -

γ

 Mitochondrial DNA synthesis +
 δ  Processive, lagging strand synthesis(forms and elongates Okazaki fragments from primer) +
 ε  Processive, leading strand synthesis +

questions.text: A 3-year-old child develops these lesions over face. The probable diagnosis is _____
questions.solution:
The given image shows skin lesions characterized by shiny, pearly white, umbilicated papules. This description points to Molluscum contagiosum.

  • The age of peak incidence is reported as between 2 and 5 years.
  • The incubation period is variously estimated at 14 days to 6 months.
  • In children, it is mainly caused by Type I molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV-1).
  • PseudoKoebner phenomenon is seen - new lesions develop along line of trauma.
  • There is a relatively higher incidence of MCV‐2 type in adults and HIV infection.
  • Sexually transmitted Molluscum contagiosum may be present over the genital area.
  • Treatment is usually not necessary, although stimulation of the immune response can be done after destructive or inflammatory therapies with salicylic acid, trichloroacetic acid or curettage and expression

Image: Keratinocytes of stratum malpighii become enlarged and acquire eosinophilic inclusion bodies - Henderson-Patterson bodies or molluscum bodies that contain virus particles.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male met with a road traffic accident and is now having multiple episodes of vomiting.On examination , GCS was 10 ,he was drowsy and his blood pressure is high. Which reflex is responsible for elevated BP in this condition?
questions.solution:
Reflex responsible for elevated BP in head injury patient is Cushing reflex.

As he has h/o head injury with fall in GCS and vomiting there might be associated intracranial bleed and thus the intracranial pressure will be elevated.

When intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to rostral ventrolateral neurons is compromised, and the local hypoxia and hypercapnia increase the discharge of the central chemoreceptors. The resultant rise in systemic arterial pressure (Cushing reflex) tends to restore the blood flow to the medulla.

Cushing reflex causes a triad of symptoms:

  • Reflex bradycardia (via arterial baroreceptors)
  • Hypertension (with widened pulse pressure)
  • Irregular respiration (bradypnea)

 

Other options:

J Reflex

  • The juxta-pulmonary capillary receptors are C fiber endings located close to the pulmonary vessels.
  • These are stimulated when there is hyperinflation of the lung
  • Produces rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension.

Atrial Reflex Control of Heart Rate: The Bainbridge Reflex

  • The stretch receptors of the atria that elicit the Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain
  • Then efferent signals are transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase heart rate and strength of heart contraction

Bezold-Jarisch Reflex

  • Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibres in the cardiopulmonary region (e.g. Juxta capillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery)
  • Causes profound brady­cardia, hypotension and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing.

questions.text: Identify the fungus shown in the image given below which is stained by India ink dye.
questions.solution:
The image above shows the fungus cryptococcus.

The image shows India ink preparation which is employed to detect the presence of capsulated yeast, cryptococcus neoformans. It induces negative staining by creating a black, semi-opaque background that makes the capsule of the yeast clearly visible. Cryptococcus has a polysaccharide capsule which is demonstrated as clear halos against a black background.

Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that is found worldwide as a saprophyte in soil enriched with pigeon droppings. It may cause infection in immune-competent people, resulting in a flu-like illness with complete recovery.

Infection in immunocompromised people like AIDS patients or patients with hematological malignancies results in meningoencephalitis.

Mucicarmine stain can also be used in the identification of cryptococcus. The image given below shows mucicarmine stained specimen of lung tissue containing cryptococci.

Culture on Sabouraud dextrose agar (SDA) at 37'C appears as smooth, mucoid, and creamy white. The cryptococcal antigen(in serum and CSF) is sensitive and specific and can be demonstrated by the latex agglutination test.

Treatment of cryptococcal meningitis involves a combination therapy of amphotericin B with flucytosine. Fluconazole can be added with these drugs in AIDS patients to prevent relapse.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, M. avium, Nocardia etc.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text:
A man encounters a bear while trekking. His flight-or-fight response is activated which affects his cardiac function. Match the following terms with the cardiac function they represent.

(SA - sinoatrial)

Term Cardiac function
1. Inotropy a. Cardiac relaxation rate
2. Chronotropy b. SA node firing rate
3. Dromotropy c. Conduction velocity
4. Lusitropy d. Cardiac excitability 
  e. Cardiac contractility
questions.solution:
The correctly matched option is 1 - e, 2 - b, 3 - c, 4 - a. 

Term Cardiac function
1. Inotropy e. Cardiac contractility 
2. Chronotropy b. SA node firing rate
3. Dromotropy c. Conduction velocity
4. Lusitropy a. Cardiac relaxation rate

Inotropy is the effect of the autonomic system or drugs on cardiac contractility. It is related to the amount of calcium available in cardiac myocytes during contraction. Positive inotropy is an increase in strength of cardiac contraction. Negative inotropy results in decreased cardiac contraction strength. 

Chronotropy is the effect of the autonomic system or drugs on heart rate. Positive chronotropy, produced by an increased rate of phase 4 depolarisation, results in increased heart rate. Negative chronotropy describes a decreased heart rate. 

Dromotropy is the effect of the autonomic system or drugs on conduction velocity, especially in the AV node. This is brought about by changes in action potential upstroke and refractory periods. Positive dromotropy refers to increased conduction velocity while negative dromotropy refers to decreased conduction velocity. 

Lusitropy is the effect of the autonomic system or drugs on the rate of cardiac relaxation or diastole. Positive and negative lusitropy refer to increased and decreased cardiac relaxation rates respectively. 

The flight-or-fight response, mediated by the sympathetic nervous system, results in positive inotropy, chronotropy, dromotropy, and lusitropy. The parasympathetic nervous system has the opposite effect.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female came to OPD with a tingling sensation in her legs and hands. The oral examination shows the following features. Which of the following investigations will be useful in diagnosing the vitamin deficiency seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
RBC glutathione reductase activity will be useful in diagnosing the riboflavin deficiency that this patient has. The image shows cheilosis and angular stomatitis which point towards riboflavin deficiency. The nutritional status of riboflavin can be assessed by measuring the activity of the RBC glutathione reductase.

Deficiency state of riboflavin is characterized by the following signs and symptoms:

  • Cheilosis: pallor in the angle of mouth and fissuring of lips, which extends radially to skin.
  • Glossitis: tongue becomes smooth, loss of papilla (magenta-colored tongue).
  • Eyes: keratitis, conjunctivitis, corneal vascularisation.
  • Other features: Seborrheic dermatitis, anemia.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used for the treatment of motion sickness?
questions.solution:
Promethazine is used for motion sickness. It is an antihistaminic agent that acts as an antagonist of H1 receptors. It also has central anticholinergic activity that is responsible for its antiemetic action.

Drugs used in the treatment of motion sickness are:

  • Anticholinergic agents (muscarinic receptor antagonists) such as scopolamine (hyoscine) and dicyclomine.
  • Antihistamines (H1 antagonists) are primarily used for treating motion sickness and postoperative emesis.  

Scopolamine transdermal patches should be given prophylactically as it is less effective once symptoms start. It is applied behind the ear at least 4-12 hours before an anticipated exposure to motion. Dry mouth and sedation are common side effects.

First-generation antihistamines such as promethazine, dimenhydrinate, chlorpheniramine, diphenhydramine, cyclizine, and meclizine are effective in controlling nausea and vomiting in motion sickness. Sedation is a common side effect of these drugs. Second-generation antihistamines like cetirizine and fexofenadine are ineffective in the treatment of motion sickness.

questions.text: The mode of gene transmission from one bacterium to another through bacteriophage is known as?
questions.solution:
Transduction is the transfer of a portion of DNA from one bacterium to another by a bacteriophage.

Transduction can be defined as the transfer of a portion of DNA from one bacterium to another by a bacteriophage. This type of horizontal gene transfer may occur by two mechanisms:

  • Lytic cycle - In the lytic cycle, also known as the virulent cycle, a large number of progeny phages build up inside the host bacterium; eventually, the host cell ruptures, releasing the bacteriophages. Some of the bacteriophages will now contain bacterial DNA, which can then be transferred to other bacteria.
  • Lysogenic cycle - In the temperate or non-lytic cycle, the host bacterium is not lysed. Rather, the phage DNA becomes integrated with the bacterial chromosome. This phage DNA multiplies with the host cell and is transferred to daughter cells. 

Option A - Conjugation is the method of gene transfer in bacteria that involves physical contact by a male or donor bacterium with a female or recipient bacterium through an extracellular protein extrusion or appendage called the sex pili. The genetic material that is transferred is usually derived from plasmids. The bacteria that possess the ability to form the sex pili contain the F+ plasmid and are designated as F+. The F+ bacteria can transfer a single strand of the F+ plasmid DNA to F- bacteria via the sex pili. 

Option C - Transformation is the direct uptake of naked DNA by the bacterial cell from the environment. Several bacteria such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Neisseria undergo transformation. 

Option D - Transposition is a process of gene transfer that involves special segments of DNA called transposons (jumping genes).

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with adenocarcinoma of the esophagus has finished his second round of chemotherapy. He was having severe bouts of vomiting after the first round of chemotherapy which was not controlled by any drug. What is the mechanism of the drug to be prescribed for refractory chemotherapy-induced vomiting?
questions.solution:
The drugs prescribed in refractory chemotherapy-induced vomiting (CINV) are cannabinoid-1 receptor agonists. Dronabinol and nabilone are examples of these drugs.

Cannabinoid-1 (CB1) receptor agonists act on the CB1 receptors on neurons and around the emetic center. Dronabinol or delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol is a natural cannabinoid obtained from the marijuana plant and nabilone is a synthetic cannabinoid. Dronabinol can also be used to stimulate appetite in AIDS-associated anorexia.

Refractory CINV refers to vomiting that occurs with subsequent chemotherapy cycles when prophylactic antiemetics were ineffective in previous cycles.

Acute CINV is the occurrence of nausea and vomiting within a few minutes to several hours after chemotherapy administration and typically resolves within 24 hours.

Delayed CINV is the occurrence of nausea and vomiting after 24 hours of chemotherapy administration and may last for 6-7 days.

Other options:

Option B: 5HT3 antagonists are the most effective for acute CINV and post-operative nausea and vomiting. The drugs used are ondansetron, granisetron, dolasetron, and palonosetron. Palonosetron is the long-acting drug in this group. These drugs are effective in acute CINV. However, palonosetron when combined with neurokinase-1 antagonist netupitant is effective in late CINV as well. These drugs are available as tablets, oral solutions and,  intravenous formulations. Granisetron is available as a transdermal patch.

Option C: Neurokinase-1 receptor (neuropeptide substance-P receptor) antagonists are effective in delayed CINV. the drugs in this group are aprepitant, fosaprepitant, rolapitant and netupitant.

Option D: Dopamine-2 receptor antagonists act at D-2 receptors in the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ), reducing the excitatory neurotransmitter release. Metoclopramide (effective in delayed emesis) and promethazine (not effective in CINV) are examples. The main adverse effects of these drugs are extrapyramidal reactions like dystonia, drug-induced Parkinson's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best sign to indicate adequate growth in an infant with a birth weight of 2.8 kg?

choices.text: Increase in length of 25 centimeters in the first year
Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year
Anterior fontanelle closure by 6 months of age
Weight under 75th percentile and height under 25th percentile

questions.solution:
The best sign to indicate adequate growth in an infant is an increase in length of 25 centimeters in the first year. The growth velocity is the rate of increase in height in one year and varies with age.

The average growth velocity is 25 cm/year in the first year (birth-12 months) and an infant will be 75 cm tall at 1 year. The height velocity is 10 cm/year from 12-24 months and at 2 years, the height is 90 cm. The height velocity is 8 cm/year from 24-36 months. At 4 years, the child is 100 cm tall. After this, the child gains about 6 cm every year until 12 years. 

If growth velocity is lower than expected for age, the child is likely to be suffering from a pathological cause of short stature.

Other options:

Option B: During the first 3 months of age, the weight gain is about 20-40 grams per day. From 4 months of age till 1 year of age, the weight gain is about 400 grams per month. The weight of an infant doubles his birth weight at 5 months of age and triples at 1 year of age and quadruples at 2 years of age.

Option C: The anterior fontanelle closes by 18 months of age.

Option D: According to WHO growth charts, weight under the 75th percentile and height under the 25th percentile do not indicate adequate growth.

questions.text:
A patient presented with tendon xanthomas. His lipid profile showed serum cholesterol levels to be 283 mg/dL and serum LDL to be 202 mg/dL. He was started on lovastatin. What is the likely diagnosis?

LDL - Low-density lipoprotein
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation with tendon xanthomas and elevated serum LDL (low-density lipoprotein) and elevated serum cholesterol points to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia (FH).

Familial hypercholesterolemia (type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia) is an inherited disorder due to defects in LDL receptors. This defect causes a decrease in the uptake of LDL and cholesterol. As a result, the blood levels of both LDL and cholesterol are elevated. Such patients are at increased risk to develop atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease.

Features of FH: 

  • Painful polyarthritis and tendinitis are common.
  • Physical findings seen are corneal arcus and tendon xanthomas over Achilles tendon and the dorsum of hands. Xanthomas are tumorous masses produced by foamy cell clusters (lipid-laden macrophages) found in the connective tissue of the skin and in tendons.

Diagnosis is done clinically based on hypercholesterolemia with 

  • LDL >190 mg/dL, 
  • Family history of hypercholesterolemia and/or
  • Premature coronary artery disease.

Treatment includes lifestyle changes, restriction of a fatty diet, and pharmacotherapy with statins in heterozygous FH patients.

Recent drugs for specific treatment of homozygous FH are:

  • Lomitapide, a microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP) inhibitor, and
  • Mipomersen, an antisense oligonucleotide against apoB.

The image below shows Achilles tendon xanthoma and a plain lateral radiograph of both ankles showing bilateral symmetrical swellings (arrows) superior to the calcaneum respectively. 

 

Other options

Option B: Tangier’s disease is a hypolipoproteinemia caused by a mutation of the ABCA1 gene. Enlarged orange tonsils are pathognomonic. Low HDL levels are seen. There is an increased risk for atherosclerosis.

The image below shows enlarged yellow-orange colored tonsils in Tangier's disease.

 

Option C: Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency causes type I hyperlipoproteinemia due to defects in LPL or apo C-II. Eruptive xanthomas are seen. Chylomicrons and VLDL are elevated. LDL and HDL are low. There is no risk for coronary disease.

Option D: Familial hyperchylomicronemia syndrome is caused due to either LPL deficiency, ApoC-II deficiency, ApoA-V deficiency, or GPIHBP1 mutation. Clinically, patients present with recurrent episodes of severe abdominal pain due to acute pancreatitis. The retinal blood vessels may be opalescent and are called lipemia retinalis. Increased levels of triglycerides (mostly >1000 mg/dL) is seen. The risk of premature coronary heart disease is low.

questions.text: Which of the following parts of the gastrointestinal tract is not supplied by the superior mesenteric artery?

choices.text: Distal part of the ascending colon

questions.solution:
The superior mesenteric artery does not supply the proximal duodenum. The coeliac trunk supplies the proximal duodenum (till ampulla of Vater).

The superior mesenteric artery supplies the distal duodenum, jejunum, ileum, appendix, cecum, ascending colon, and proximal 2/3rd of the transverse colon. 

The superior mesenteric artery (SMA) is a branch of the abdominal aorta and originates at the level of the lower border of the L1 vertebra in the transpyloric plane. It descends anterior to the uncinate process of the pancreas and the third part of the duodenum and posterior to the body of the pancreas and the splenic vein. The left renal vein separates it from the aorta posteriorly.

Image showing blood supply of colon

questions.text: You can hear a ‘lub-dub’ sound while auscultating in the medicine ward. The ‘dub’ sound is produced by the closure of valve X. Which of the following phases succeeds the opening of X?
questions.solution:

questions.text: The following Indices are used for measuring disability except
questions.solution:
PQLI includes infant mortality rate, literacy, and life expectancy at 1 year whereas other indicators are directly related to the measurement of disability.

 Sullivan's index is also known as disability-free life expectancy (DFLE) or active life expectancy. It is the average number of years an individual is expected to live free of disability if the current patterns of mortality and disability continue to apply. It doesn’t take into account premature death.
Disability-free life expectancy = (Life expectancy) - (the duration of the disability).

DALY is the best measure of the overall burden of a disease in a defined population and the effectiveness of interventions. It can measure both mortality and disability together.
DALY = Years of lost life (YLL) + Years lost of disability (YLD)

HALE (Health Adjusted Life Expectancy) is an indicator that can be used to estimate the number of years a newborn is expected to live in full health based on the current rates of ill health and mortality. HALE is calculated using the life expectancy at birth with an adjustment for time spent in poor health. It captures both fatal and non-fatal health outcomes of average levels of population health. It is also sensitive to changes over time or differences between countries in the distribution of health states.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought by his parents with complaints of diarrhea and dermatitis. The child had neutral aminoaciduria and a positive Obermeyer test result. Which of the following is the precursor of the vitamin that is deficient in the patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of pellagra secondary to Hartnup disease. The vitamin deficiency in this condition is niacin. The precursor of niacin is tryptophan.

Hartnup's disease which is due to impaired renal and intestinal absorption of tryptophan and other neutral amino acids. It is characterized by a varied clinical presentation including ataxia (lack of muscle control), delayed mental development, diarrhea, and dermatitis i.e, pellagra-like symptoms (as tryptophan is a precursor of niacin)

Diagnosis is based on aminoaciduria and increased excretion of indole compounds detected by the Obermeyer test.

Niacin/vitamin B3 is a constituent of NAD and NADP. Niacin deficiency causes pellagra (3Ds):

  1. Diarrhea
  2. Dermatitis (Casal necklace)
  3. Dementia

Patients can also present with bright red glossitis, stomatitis, depression, seizures, insomnia, and delirium.

The image below shows the Casal necklace—a ring-like rash seen around the neck caused by the deficiency of niacin.

questions.text:
Identify the type of enzymatic inhibition shown in the image below.

Km: Michaelis constant
questions.solution:
The given image represents the mechanism of non-competitive enzyme inhibition.

In non-competitive inhibition, an inhibitor binds to the allosteric site of the enzyme. This leads to a conformational change in the substrate-binding site which prevents the binding of the substrate to the enzyme. The free enzyme molecules have the same affinity to the substrate because Km remains the same.

In this type of inhibition, Km remains the same.

In enzyme kinetics, Vmax is the reaction rate when the enzyme is saturated with the substrate. Km (Michaelis constant) is the substrate concentration at which the enzyme achieves ½ Vmax.

Km indicates the affinity of the enzyme to the substrate. 

Other options:

Option A: Feedback inhibition is the process by which the enzyme activity is inhibited by the final product of the biosynthetic pathway.

Option B: Suicide inhibition is an irreversible type of enzymatic inhibition. In this type of inhibition, the inhibitor utilizes the enzyme's own reaction mechanisms to inactivate it. The inhibitor binds to the enzyme and creates a new product which in turn irreversibly binds to the enzyme and inhibits it.

Option C: In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor molecules compete with the substrate molecules for binding with the active site of the enzyme.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy last vaccinated at 12 weeks of life presents to you with a high-grade fever, cough, and a rash. The parents say that the rash shown below started from the forehead and behind the ears, and then it spread to the neck and body. Which of the following is true regarding this child's condition?
  1. Causative agent is an RNA paramyxovirus
  2. The secondary attack rate in susceptible contacts is ≥90%
  3. Forchheimer spots are characteristic
  4. Jeryl Lynn strain of vaccine is used for prevention
  5. Most complications are due to secondary bacterial infections.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with the symptoms, incomplete vaccination history, and regional distribution of the red maculopapular rash is suggestive of measles. Options 1,2 and 5 are correct regarding this condition.

Measles is caused by a single-stranded, lipid-enveloped RNA paramyxovirus. Contact with large droplets or small-droplet aerosols is the route of transmission. Infection results in respiratory tract epithelial necrosis and lymphocytic infiltration. Clinical features include high fever, cough, coryza, and a rash.

Koplik spots appear 1-4 days before the onset of the rash. They appear as discrete red lesions with bluish-white spots at the level of the premolars. It can also involve the lips and gingiva. This is followed by the appearance of the rash that starts on the forehead, neck, and behind the ears. It then spreads to involve the torso and extremities. The image below shows Koplik's spots.

Confirmation of the diagnosis can be made by IgM assay. Affected children need to be isolated for 4 days after the beginning of the rash to prevent its spread. Management is mainly supportive by the maintenance of hydration and oxygenation. 

Most complications are secondary to bacterial infections. Pneumonia is the most common cause of death and acute otitis media is the most common complication. Croup, bronchiolitis, encephalitis, and subacute sclerosing panencephalitis are the other complications.

Secondary attack rates in susceptible contacts are usually ≥90%. Vaccination against measles is the most effective way to prevent the condition. It is contraindicated in individuals with severe immunosuppression.

Rubella, also known as German measles is a viral disease that presents with low-grade fever, sore throat, rash, and lymphadenopathy. Forchheimer spots are tiny rose-colored lesions or petechial hemorrhages seen on the soft palate. It is usually seen with the onset of the rash. The rash starts on the face and neck and then involves the torso and extremities. It is shown in the image below. 

The Jeryl Lynn strain of virus is used for vaccination against mumps. It is a systemic viral illness caused by a paramyxovirus characterized by parotitis.

RTS,S/AS01 is effective against P. Falciparum. Phase 3 trial of this vaccine has already been completed. There is a positive scientific opinion about its risk benefit balance and a phase 4 trial is under evaluation.

 

 

Related Pearl: Measles vaccine

Measles vaccine: 

  • Type: Live attenuenated, lyophilized (freeze dried), vaccine (Tissue culture vaccine- chick embryo or Human diploid cell line).

  • Strains used: 1. Edmonston Zagreb strain (most common). 

                            2. Schwartz strain.

                            3. Moraten strain.

  • Dose: 0.5ml.

  • Route: Subcutaneous.

  • Site: Right arm (usually).

  • Age of administration in National immunization schedule (India): 9 months (can be lowered to 6-9 months in epidemics and malnutrition) and 16-24 months.

  • Diluent for reconstitution: Distilled water or sterile water. (To be used within 4 hours after reconstitutuion).

  • Measles (and MMR) vaccine can lead to Toxic shock syndrome.

  • Measles vaccine is contraindicated in pregnancy.

  • Cold chain temperature for storage: +2 to +8 degree Celcius.

  • Protective efficacy: >90% with one dose; >99% with two doses.

  • Duration of protection: Life long.

  • IP of vaccine induced measles: 7 days.

  • Ideal gap between two successive doses: 6 months.

Related Pearl: Open Vial Policy

Open vial policy allows for reuse of partially used multidose vials of applicable vaccines under the Universal Immunization Programme in subsequent sessions up to 4 weeks subject to certain conditions and thereby reducing vaccine wastage.

It is applicable only for DPT, TT, hepatitis B vaccine, OPV and liquid pentavalent vaccine.

It is not applicable for BCG, measles, rotavirus vaccines and JE vaccines.

Vaccine vials opened in session-site can be use in more than one session up to four weeks if expiry date has not passed, if storage and transport was appropriate, no contamination has occurred in vial septum, asepsis in withdrawing was practiced and if vaccine vial monitor has not reached discard point.

Open vials should not be submerged in water.

Ensure all opened vials have recorded date and time of opening.

At the end of a session, all vaccines should be returned to the cold chain point and segregated as re-usable and non-reusable.

All open vials of BCG, measles and JE must be destroyed after 48 hours or before next session, whichever is earlier.

In case of any adverse events following immunization, all open vials should not be discarded until investigation is complete.

All vials must be transported in zipper bags in the vaccine carrier and recorded in stock register.

Ice packs used should be well sealed.

questions.text: A patient with a history of pharyngitis presents with the given clinical finding. Involvement of which part of the brain is likely to be responsible for this given finding?
questions.solution:
The given history of pharyngitis and the gif showing random irregular movements of the limb and the face is suggestive of Sydenham's chorea, a complication of rheumatic fever. The choreic movements are caused by the destruction of D2 neurons of the neostriatum. The neostriatum consists of the caudate nucleus and putamen.

Sydenham's chorea is characterized by involuntary, purposeless, jerky movements which mainly affect the head and upper limbs. In the tongue, it is visible as the characteristic darting movements.

Nomenclature of basal ganglia:

  • Corpus striatum: Caudate nucleus + putamen+ globus pallidus
  • Lentiform nucleus: Putamen + globus pallidus
  • Neostriatum: Caudate nucleus + putamen

questions.text: A one-year-old baby is brought to the emergency room with bluish discolouration of the skin and rapid breathing. His mother reveals a history of congenital heart disease in the baby and adds that this episode was provoked by an incessant cry. Which of the following is least likely to be used for managing this child?
questions.solution:
The emergency depicted is suggestive of a paroxysmal hypercyanotic attack/cyanotic spell. The administration of intravenous nitroglycerin is of no use and can worsen the condition, as it decreases the peripheral resistance.

Children with congenital cyanotic heart disease are prone to develop cyanotic spells. Precipitating factors include crying, defecation, feeding, wakening from sleep, dehydration, fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, and events provoking an agitation.

They are characterized by:

  • Period of uncontrolled crying/panic/irritability
  • Rapid and deep breathing
  • Increased cyanosis
  • Limpness and lethargy
  • Reduced murmur intensity
    (signifying substantial blood flow reduction across right ventricular outflow tract)

Management options in this child include the following:

  • Calm the child and minimize stimuli
  • Place in the knee-chest position.
  • Administer oxygen
  • Subcutaneous morphine (not in excess of 0.2mg/kg)
  • IV sodium bicarbonate (for correction of the ongoing metabolic acidosis)
  • IV phenylephrine (as it increases the systemic vascular resistance)
  • IV propranolol (as it reduces the pulmonary infundibular spasms in TOF)
  • If the spell is resistant to all the above-said measures, then intubation and sedation of the child is required to break the spell.

Note:- Paroxysmal Hypercyanotic spells may also be referred to as Tet spells/ Blue spells/ Hypoxic spells. Though commonly associated with Tetralogy of fallout, they can be associated with other forms of pulmonary stenosis with ventricular septal defect as well.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old morbidly obese diabetic woman presents with a history of failed metformin therapy. She is started on canagliflozin. Which of the following side effects are associated with canagliflozin?
  1. Urinary tract infections
  2. Weight gain
  3. Increased risk of fractures
  4. Increased risk of lower extremity amputation
questions.solution:
The side effects associated with canagliflozin are urinary tract infections, increased risk of fractures, and lower extremity amputations.

Canagliflozin is a sodium-glucose transporter 2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor. Other SGLT-2 inhibitors include dapagliflozin and empagliflozin. They act by inhibiting the SGLT-2 transporter which is present on the proximal segment of the renal tubule. It is responsible for the reabsorption of 80-90% of filtered glucose. It inhibits glucose reabsorption resulting in glycosuria and a change in the renal threshold.

SGLT2 inhibitors can cause mild weight loss and reduction in blood pressure. Drugs like empagliflozin and canagliflozin are found to reduce major cardiovascular events.

The common side effects include urinary tract infections and genital mycotic infections due to the high glucose content of the urine. There is a risk of the development of diabetic ketoacidosis. It increases the risk of fractures and lower limb amputations due to the creation of an imbalance with the minerals and circulating parathormone and vitamin D. Since SGLT2 inhibitors depend on the rate of glucose filtration to be effective, potency decreases if given in stage 3 kidney disease (GFR 60–30 mL/min).

questions.text: Which of the following findings suggests that the baby was live-born in a case of infanticide?

choices.text: Gelatinous tissue in the middle ear
Weight of lung 1/35th of body weight

questions.solution:
The baby will be considered live-born if the weight of the lung is 1/35th of the body weight.

Autopsy findings to differentiate before and after respiration:

Autopsy findings Before respiration After respiration
1. Shape of chest Flat; chest circumference is 1–2 cm less than the abdominal circumference Dome or arch-shaped
2. Position of the diaphragm At or above the 4th/5th rib At or below the 6th/7th rib
3. Lung margins Sharp Rounded
4. Lung consistency Dense, firm, non-crepitant Soft, spongy, elastic, crepitant
5. Lung weight 1/70th of body weight 1/35th of body weight
6. Lung color Uniformly reddish-brown or bluish-red Mottled or marbled appearance
7. Hydrostatic test Specific gravity is 1040–1050 Specific gravity is 940
8. Stomach Contains only mucin and sinks in water Contains mucin and air and floats in water
9. Middle ear Contains gelatinous embryonic connective tissue Air replaces the embryonic tissue

 

Other tests for live birth:

  • Breslau’s first life test (also known as Hydrostatic test/Raygat’s test) - The organ tested is the lung. It is based on the ability of the lung to sink or float in water.
  • Breslau's second life test: It is based on the air entering stomach and intestine during respiration in a live-born fetus. The stomach and intestine are removed by tying double ligatures at each end and placed in water to check if they float or sink.
  • Wreden’s test – This test is based on changes in the middle ear after birth
  • Fodere’s test – This test is based on the increase in the weight of the lungs due to increased blood flow after birth. The weight of the unrespired lung is 30–40 g, whereas the weight of respired lung is 60–66 g.
  • Ploucquet’s test – This is based on the ratio of the weight of the lung to the weight of the body in unrespired and respired lungs.
    • Unrespired lungs - 1/70
    • Respired lungs - 1/35

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his mother with complaints of biting his lips and nails. On examination, the child has delayed developmental milestones, spasticity, and dystonia. Nail findings are as shown in the image below. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated uric acid levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with the image showing self-mutilation and laboratory values showing hyperuricemia is most likely suggestive of Lesch-Nyhan disease.

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder due to a complete deficiency of the hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). This deficiency results in an inability to salvage hypoxanthine or guanine leading to increased levels of phospho-ribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP). Increased PRPP leads to increased purine synthesis, which is later degraded to uric acid. Increased hypoxanthine is also converted to uric acid.

The patients have intellectual disability, behaviors of self-injury like lip and finger biting, developmental delay, muscle dystonia, and extrapyramidal symptoms. 

Diagnosis is made by the elevated levels of uric acid and by HGPRT enzyme assay.

The image given below shows the metabolism of hypoxanthine and guanine by HGPRT.

Other options:

Option A: Autism mainly presents with problems in social communication and social interaction. They have poor verbal and non-verbal communication, absence of eye contact, repetitive behaviors like lining up toys or flipping objects, echolalia, etc. Intellectual impairment may or may not be present.

Option C: Patients with severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) present with infections. Diarrhea, pneumonia, otitis media, sepsis, and cutaneous infections are common presentations. It is caused by various genetic mutations that lead to the absence of T and B-cell function. They have a low lymphocyte count.

Option D: Tourette’s disorder is characterized by sudden repetitive, non-rhythmic motor movements or sounds. They present with loud grunting or barking noises or shouting obscene words. Motor tics include tongue protrusion, sniffing, hopping, squatting, blinking, or nodding.

questions.text: An exclusively breastfed newborn was brought with vomiting and diarrhea that developed since birth. On examination, the baby is jaundiced and has hepatomegaly. Blood glucose level was low and erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level was elevated. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an exclusively breastfed infant with vomiting, diarrhea, jaundice, hypotonia, and hepatomegaly with elevated erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level is suggestive of classical galactosemia.

Classical galactosemia is an autosomal recessive disorder. The enzyme deficient here is galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT). Normally, newborns receive up to 40% of their calorie intake as lactose (glucose + galactose). Without GALT, the infant cannot metabolize galactose 1-phosphate, which accumulates and causes injury to the kidney, liver, and brain.

Clinical features include vomiting, hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, jaundice, congenital cataracts, aminoaciduria, and failure to thrive. There is an increased incidence of Escherichia coli neonatal sepsis. Long-term complications include speech delays, learning impairment, motor dysfunction, and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (in females).

The presence of galactose in urine (positive Benedict's test), elevated blood galactose level, and elevated erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level help in confirming the diagnosis.

Treatment is a galactose-free diet. Supportive therapy and the prevention of complications are important.

Other options:

Option A: Fructosuria is due to the deficiency of fructokinase. There are no symptoms except for the benign excretion of fructose in urine.

Option B: von Gierke's disease is due to glucose-6-phosphatase or translocase deficiency. It is a glycogen storage disorder (Type I).  They may develop hypoglycemia and lactic acidosis in the neonatal period, but hepatomegaly usually develops at 3–4 months. They may have doll-like facies, short stature, and a protuberant abdomen. Hyperuricemia, the elevation of triglycerides, low-density lipoproteins, and phospholipids are seen.

Option D: Hereditary fructose intolerance is due to a deficiency of fructose 1, 6-bisphosphate aldolase (aldolase B). Patients are healthy and symptom-free until fructose or sucrose is ingested. Clinical manifestations may include jaundice, hepatomegaly, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, and convulsions. It will not be seen in newborns who are exclusively on breast milk.

questions.text: A patient with Wilm's tumor undergoes renal transplantation. He is currently on corticosteroid therapy to prevent organ rejection. All of the following vaccinations could be given to this patient except?
questions.solution:
Intra-nasal/ nasal spray influenza vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine, therefore it is contraindicated in this patient as he is immunosuppressed.

Live vaccines are prepared from live or wild attenuated organisms. They are repeatedly passed through tissue cultures or chick embryos in the laboratory. With this, they lose their ability to induce full-blown infection in an individual but retain their immunogenicity. It should not be administered to patients with immunodeficiency diseases, lymphoma, leukaemia, or other malignancies. It is also not recommended in individuals on treatment with corticosteroids, antimetabolites, and alkylating agents. Unless the risk of infection exceeds the risk of harm, it is contraindicated in pregnancy. 

Live- attenuated influenza vaccine is approved for use in otherwise healthy individuals between age of 2 years and 49 years. Because the risk of transmission of the live-attenuated vaccine virus to immunocompromised individuals is unknown, it should not be used in household members of immunosuppressed individuals, health care workers, or others with close contact with immunosuppressed persons.

Intramuscular influenza vaccine is an inactivated vaccine, which can be given in the immunocompromised.

Other options:

Option A: Diptheria-pertussis-tetanus (DPT) vaccine is a combination toxoid vaccine. The toxins produced by diphtheria and tetanus bacilli are detoxicated and used to prepare the vaccine. They are highly efficacious and safe. The killed whole organism is used for the pertussis component. 

Option B: Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant vaccine. It is produced by inserting a viral gene segment into a yeast cell. It does not contain viral DNA and will not produce an infection.

Option D: Inactivated polio vaccine is a killed vaccine. As the organism cannot grow in a vaccinated individual, it can be given to an immunodeficient individual.

questions.text: A young male presents to the emergency room with severe abdominal pain. The small bowel is found to have a small infarcted area which is surgically removed. Histopathological examination of the biopsy specimen is given below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the small bowel infarction?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histopathological findings are suggestive of polyarteritis nodosa (PAN).

PAN affects small or medium-sized muscular arteries. It typically affects young adults. The patient may present with rapidly accelerating hypertension due to renal artery involvement (most common) or abdominal pain and bloody stools caused by involvement of gastrointestinal vessels.

30% of patients with PAN have chronic hepatitis B and deposits containing HBsAg-HBsAb complexes in the affected vessels.

Specific complaints related to a particular organ system may also dominate the clinical picture:

  • Renal - renal failure, hypertension
  • Musculoskeletal - arthritis, arthralgia, myalgia
  • Peripheral nervous system - Peripheral neuropathy, mononeuritis multiplex
  • Gastrointestinal tract - Abdominal pain, bleeding, bowel infarction and perforation
  • Skin - rash, purpura, cutaneous infarcts, livedo reticularis, Raynaud's phenomenon
  • Cardiac - Congestive heart failure, myocardial infarction, pericarditis
  • Genitourinary - Testicular, ovarian or epididymal pain
  • Central nervous system - Cerebral vascular accident, seizure, altered mental status
    Death usually results from gastrointestinal complications, particularly bowel infarcts and perforation, and cardiovascular causes.

Diagnosis - The diagnosis is based on the demonstration of characteristic findings of vasculitis on biopsy material. An elevated ESR is almost always present. All patients should be screened for hepatitis B and C. 

Treatment - Prednisolone and cyclophosphamide have shown favorable results. In patients with hepatitis B, antiviral therapy is used in combination with glucocorticoids and plasma exchange.

Option A: Hyperplastic arteriosclerosis is a vascular pathology seen in severe hypertension. 

Option B: Cystic medial degeneration leads to dissecting aortic aneurysm.

Option C: Mönckeberg’s arteriosclerosis does not cause infarction.

questions.text: The structure marked in the image drains into:

choices.text: Junction of superior vena cava and left brachiocephalic veins
Junction of left jugular and left subclavian veins

questions.solution:
The image shows the thoracic duct which drains into the junction of the left jugular and left subclavian veins.

Thoracic duct begins in the abdomen at T-12 vertebral level as the continuation of cisterna chyli.

  • It is usually beaded due to its numerous valves.
  • It drains the body below the diaphragm (lower limbs, pelvis, abdomen) and left half of the body above the diaphragm (thorax, upper limb, head and neck).
  • Thoracic duct passes through the aortic hiatus in the diaphragm and ascends through the posterior mediastinum between the aorta and the azygous vein.
  • At T-5 level, it deviates to the left side and ascends to pass the thoracic inlet.

Tributaries of the thoracic duct:

  • Bilateral (right and left) descending thoracic lymph trunks which convey lymph from lower intercostal spaces (6 – 11).
  • Left upper intercostal lymph trunks, which convey lymph from the upper intercostal spaces (1-5).
  • Mediastinal lymph trunks
  • Left subclavian lymph trunk
  • Left jugular lymph trunk
  • Left bronchomediastinal lymph trunk

The lymph passes through larger lymphatics and eventually collect into two large trunks, the thoracic duct and right lymphatic duct, which in turn drain into the brachiocephalic veins.

  • Thoracic duct- drains both lower limbs, left upper limb, abdomen, left halves of thorax, and left side of the head and neck regions (areas shaded green in the image).
  • Right lymphatic duct- drains right upper limb, and right halves of thorax, and right side of the head and neck regions (areas shaded blue in the image).

questions.text: According to biomedical waste management protocols, which of the following colored boxes should the instrument shown below be discarded in?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a dynamic hip screw and it should be discarded in the blue color box.

All metallic body implants except metallic sharps are discarded in the blue box. Metallic sharps (scalpels, blades, needles, etc) are discarded in white or translucent boxes.

Other options:

Option A: White (translucent) containers are puncture-proof and leakproof. It is used for the disposal of waste sharps including metals.

Option C: Yellow containers are lined with yellow non-chlorinated plastic bags. It is used for the disposal of anatomical wastes, discarded medicines, and clinical laboratory waste.

Option D: Red containers are lined with red non-chlorinated bags. Recyclable contaminated waste such as intravenous tubes, catheters, and urine bags are discarded in these containers.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman was detected with a positive antibody titer against the thyroid peroxidase enzyme. All of the following steps are catalyzed by this enzyme for the synthesis of thyroid hormones except?
questions.solution:
Iodide trapping (iodide uptake) is not catalyzed by thyroid peroxidase. Oxidation, organification, and coupling are catalyzed by it.  

Steps in synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormone: 

  • Iodide uptake: The basolateral sodium-iodide symporter (NIS) actively takes up I- (iodide) from the circulation into the follicular cells. The process of concentrating iodide in the cell is known as iodide trapping. Iodide is then transported into the colloid through a pendrin (chloride-iodide) transporter.
  • Thyroglobulin synthesis: Thyroglobulin (Tg), is a large glycoprotein rich in tyrosine residues. It is synthesized by the thyrocytes and secreted into colloid.
  • Iodination of thyroglobulin: This is regulated by the thyroid peroxidase (TPO) enzyme. TPO has three functions: 
    • Oxidation: TPO oxidizes iodine in the presence of H2O2
    • Organification: TPO links tyrosine residues of thyroglobulin with iodine (I2) to form monoiodotyrosine (MIT), diiodotyrosine (DIT)
    • Coupling reactions: TPO combines iodinated tyrosine residues to make MIT + DIT = T3 (triiodothyronine), DIT + DIT = T4 (tetraiodothyronine)
  • Storage: Thyroid hormones are bound to thyroglobulin and stored in the follicular lumen as colloids. The colloid has hormone reserves for 2-3 months
  • Release: Iodinated thyroglobulin is cleaved by lysosomal proteolytic enzymes in the colloid from the thyroid cells. This releases thyroxine and triiodothyronine into the peripheral blood. 
  • Peripheral T3 conversion: T4 undergoes deiodination in extrathyroidal tissue to form T3, which is the active form of the hormone.

questions.text:
Match the following chemotherapeutic agents with their adverse effects.
Drugs Adverse effects
1. Bleomycin a. Peripheral neuropathy
2. Doxorubicin b. Hand foot syndrome.
3. Vincristine c. Pulmonary fibrosis
4. Capecitabine d. Cardiotoxicity
questions.solution:
The correct match is;

Drugs Adverse effects
1. Bleomycin

c. Pulmonary fibrosis
2. Doxorubicin

d. Cardiotoxicity
3. Vincristine

a. Peripheral neuropathy
4. Capecitabine

b. Hand-foot syndrome.

Bleomycin is an anticancer antibiotic used for the treatment of squamous cell cancer and Hodgkin lymphoma. It chelates copper or iron and produces superoxide ions that damage DNA. Side effects are mucocutaneous toxicity and pulmonary fibrosis.

Doxorubicin is an anthracycline that is widely used in clinical practice as a chemotherapeutic agent. It is most commonly used as a part of regimens with other agents like cyclophosphamide, cisplatin, and 5-FU in several malignancies including: 

  • Breast cancer
  • Endometrial cancer
  • Ovarian cancer
  • Soft-tissue sarcoma
  • Neuroblastoma
  • Ewing's sarcoma
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma
  • ALL
  • Multiple myeloma
  • Hodgkin's and Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma

Cardiotoxicity is a known side-effect of doxorubicin. Therefore, careful monitoring is required for doxorubicin. Specifically, doxorubicin requires dose adjustment during or after radiotherapy in order to prevent radiation toxicity.

Vincristine is a vinca alkaloid that acts during the M phase of the cell cycle. It causes microtubule disruptions, thereby preventing cellular replication. Side effects are neuropathy, and SIADH.

 Capecitabine is a pyrimidine analog that is classified as an antimetabolite agent. Side effects are diarrhea, hand-foot syndrome, and myelosuppression.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents with small bumps on the cheeks and nasolabial folds as shown in the image below. She is a known case of seizure disorder on medication. On examination, there is a hypopigmented oval patch on the lower back. What is the inheritance pattern of this disease?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of facial angiofibromas, seizures, and a hypomelanotic oval patch on the back suggests tuberous sclerosis (TS). It has an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance.

Tuberous sclerosis is a multisystem disorder with an autosomal dominant inheritance mode. The mutations involve the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16.

Tuberous sclerosis is diagnosed when at least two major or one major plus two minor features are present.

  • Major features: 
    • Cortical dysplasias (including tubers and cerebral white matter migration lines)
    • Subependymal nodules
    • Subependymal giant cell astrocytoma
    • Facial angiofibromas (≥3) or forehead plaque
    • Ungual fibromas (≥2)
    • Hypomelanotic macules (≥3, ≥5 mm in diameter)
    • Shagreen patch
    • Multiple retinal nodular hamartomas
    • Cardiac rhabdomyoma
    • Renal angiomyolipoma
    • Pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis
  • Minor features: 
    • Dental enamel pits (>3)
    • Intraoral fibromas (≥2)
    • Retinal achromic patch
    • Confetti skin lesions
    • Nonrenal hamartomas
    • Multiple renal cysts

The CT image given below shows subependymal nodules seen in TS.

Note: When these lesions are calcified, they project into the ventricular cavity having a candle-drip appearance.


Children are usually treated symptomatically with anticonvulsants and surgery for tumors. Vigabatrin can be used as a first-line agent for the treatment of infantile spasms in patients with tuberous sclerosis. Medical treatment with an mTOR inhibitor everolimus may be used for treating subependymal giant cell astrocytoma, and renal angiomyolipomas. Sirolimus, another mTOR inhibitor, is approved for management of lymphangioleiomyomatosis.

questions.text:
A stain present on the clothes of a murder victim is being examined. Which of the following tests would help determine whether that particular stain is due to blood?
  1. Phenolphthalein test
  2. Takayama test
  3. Precipitin test
  4. Teichmann’s test
  5. Latte’s method
questions.solution:
The phenolphthalein test, Takayama test, and Teichmann’s test can be used to determine if a particular stain at a crime scene is due to blood.

Tests for determining if a stain is due to blood include the following:

Benzidine test - It is the best preliminary test for blood and is based on the peroxidase activity of blood, which changes the color of the reagent. A negative reaction rules out the presence of blood (high sensitivity). False positive reactions can occur with substances like pus, saliva, milk, rust, or bacteria.

Phenolphthalein or Kastle-Meyer test - This test is done by adding phenolphthalein reagent and hydrogen peroxide to the extracted stain sample. Pink or purple color indicates a positive test. This test is more specific for blood than the benzidine test.

Haemin crystal test or Teichmann’s test - It is done by adding glacial acetic acid and a small crystal of sodium chloride to a stain. If bloodstain is present, faint yellowish-red to brownish-black rhombic crystals of hemin or hematin chloride appear.

Haemochromogen crystal test or Takayama test - The Takayama reagent (sodium hydroxide, pyridine, and glucose) is added to a suspected stain. If bloodstain is present, pink feathery crystals of haemochromogen or reduced alkaline hematin appear in a few minutes.

Spectroscopic test - It is the most definitive test for detecting the presence of blood in both recent and old stains. It is based on the property of blood pigments to absorb rays from the spectrum, producing characteristic dark absorption bands. 

Other options:

Statement 3: The precipitin test does not determine if the stain is due to blood. Rather, it can detect whether a particular stain is of human origin or from a lower animal. The origin of skin, flesh, bone, blood, or even secretions, such as saliva, milk, and semen, is determined by this test.

Statement 5: Latte’s crust method is used on a known blood stain to determine common blood groups such as ABO, MNS, and Rh systems.

questions.text: What is the correct order of a family cycle?

choices.text: Formation, extension, complete extension, dissolution, contraction, complete contraction
Formation, contraction, extension, complete extension, dissolution, complete contraction
Formation, contraction, complete contraction, extension, complete extension, dissolution
Formation, extension, complete extension, contraction, complete contraction, dissolution

questions.solution:
The order of the family cycle is formation, extension, complete extension, contraction, complete contraction and dissolution.

Related Pearl: The Family as a Social Organization

  • A family is a group of biologically related individuals living together under the same roof and eating from a common kitchen.
  • It is the most primary and basic unit of all societies.
  • The basic and arbitrary model of a family cycle has six phases:

 

Phase

Beginning

End

1

Formation

Marriage

Birth of 1st child

2

Extension

Birth of 1st child

Birth of last child

3

Complete extension

Birth of last child

1st child leaves home

4

Contraction

1st child leaves home

Last child leaves parental home

5

Completed contraction

Last child leaves parental home

Death of 1st spouse

6

Dissolution

Death of 1st spouse

Death of survivor
  • Types of families:
    • A nuclear family or elementary family consists of only the married couple and their offspring while they are dependants.
    • The term new family is applied when nuclear families are younger than 10 years and consist of parents and children.
    • A joint family or extended family consists of a number of married couples and their children who live together in the same household with usually the men being related by blood. All property in joint families is held in common with the family income going into a common pocket. A senior male member is usually the head of the family who makes decisions.
    • A three generation family is one where there are representatives from three different generations in one house.
    • A communal family is one in which all the members play a part in its management.
  • Functions of the family:
    • Residence (patrilocal and matrilocal)
    • Division of labour
    • Reproduction and raising children
    • Socialization and social care
    • Economic functions
  • Problems families are those that lag behind the rest of the community in terms of standard and quality of life of its members.
  • Broken families are those in which the parental or family system has been disrupted by separation, divorce or death.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is attached to the area marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
The area marked in the image is the palmar aspect of the first metacarpal. The opponens pollicis muscle is inserted at this site.

Opponens pollicis:

  • Origin:  Tubercle of the trapezium and flexor retinaculum
  • Insertion: Whole length of the lateral border and the adjoining lateral half of the palmar aspect of the first metacarpal.
  • Action: Flexes the metacarpal bone of the thumb.
The intrinsic muscles of the hand are organized into three groups plus a superficial muscle.
  • Thenar muscles - Flexor pollicis brevis, Abductor pollicis brevis, Opponens pollicis, Adductor pollicis
  • Hypothenar muscles- Abductor digiti minimi, Flexor digiti minimi brevis, Opponens digiti minimi
  • Interossei and lumbricals
  • Palmaris brevis - Superficial muscle that lies beneath the ulnar palmar skin
MUSCLE ORIGIN INSERTION ACTION
Flexor pollicis brevis
Superficial head:
  1. Distal border of the flexor retinaculum
