questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of bias in a case-control study?
questions.solution:
Hawthorne bias is not seen in case-control studies. This bias occurs when the subjects change their attitude/ actions while under observation. This distorts the results of the cohort or experimental studies.

The bias that are seen in the case-control study are:

  1. Confounding
  2. Recall bias
  3. Selection bias
  4. Berkesonian bias
  5. Interviewer's bias

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

  • Bias due to confounding: It can be removed by matching.
  • Memory or recall bias as cases and controls may not be able to recall specifics about their history.
  • Selection bias: Cases and controls may not be representative of the population or there may be systematic differences between both.
  • Berkesonian bias: This type of selection bias occurs in hospital cases and controls as the admission rates for people with different diseases may differ.
  • Interviewer’s bias: If the interviewer knows the hypothesis and who the cases are, he/she may interview the cases more thoroughly than the controls. It can be eliminated by double blinding.
  • Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias: It is due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. For example, a case-control study is carried out to study the relation between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI), being cases interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

questions.text: A 19-year-old athlete presented with pain, numbness and fatigue of the right arm. Angiography revealed decreased blood supply through the blood vessels anastomosing near the surgical neck of the humerus. The thrombus is likely to be present  in:
questions.solution:
The thrombus is likely to be present in the third part of the axillary artery.

The anterior and posterior circumflex humeral arteries, which are branches of 3rd part of the axillary artery, anastomose at the surgical neck of the humerus.

Branches of 3rd part of axillary artery are:

  • Anterior circumflex humeral arteries
  • Posterior circumflex humeral arteries
  • Subscapular artery (not involved in the anastomosis)

Clinical significance:

  • Fracture of surgical neck: It is the commonest site among all proximal humerus fractures due to its inherent weakness. Fracture at this site may cause injury to the posterior circumflex humeral artery and the axillary nerve that accompanies it.
  • Positional compression of axillary artery: In some athletes who are involved with throwing movement, as in baseball players, repeated movement of the humerus may cause compression of the distal part of the axillary artery. This may lead to thrombosis or aneurysm resulting in arm ischemia.

questions.text:
Given below is the procedure done under 'Nalgonda technique'. What is the purpose of this technique?
Add lime + alum
↓
Flocculation
↓
Sedimentation
↓
Filtration

choices.text: Steeping pulses in hot water for toxin removal
Air floatation of grains to remove ergot

questions.solution:
Nalgonda technique is used for defluoridation of water which involves the addition of lime and alum followed by flocculation, sedimentation, and filtration.

Fluorosis occurs when drinking water contains excess amounts of fluorine, in the range of 3-5mg/L. It is endemic in parts of India- Andhra Pradesh (Nellore, Prakasam), Telangana(Nalgonda), Punjab, Haryana, Karnataka, Kerala, Tamil Nadu. 

Symptoms correspond to levels of fluoride intake:

  • Dental fluorosis: (1.5mg/L)
  • Skeletal fluorosis: (3-6mg/L) 
  • Crippling fluorosis: (>10mg/L)

Genu valgum and osteoporosis of the lower limb are seen in a newer form of fluorosis in Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh. It is seen in people consuming jawar (sorghum), as it promotes greater retention of ingested fluoride.

The given images show dental fluorosis and skeletal fluorosis (interosseous-membrane-calcification), respectively:

 

Interventions for Fluorosis 

  • Change the drinking water source with a lower fluoride content (0.5 to 0.8 mg/L). Running surface water contains lower quantities of fluorides than groundwater sources.
  • The National Environmental Engineering Research Institute, Nagpur developed a technique for removing fluoride by a chemical treatment called the Nalgonda technique. 
  • Fluoride supplements should not be prescribed for children who drink fluoridated water.
  • The use of fluoride toothpaste in areas of endemic fluorosis is not recommended for children up to 6 years of age

Other options:

Superchlorination of water is the addition of large amounts of chlorine to the water, for disinfection. The excess is later removed. It is done for heavily polluted water with fluctuating quality.

Steeping pulses in hot water for toxin removal is done for Lathyrism. The toxin beta oxalyl amino alanine in its crystalline form is water-soluble. The pulse is soaked in boiling water for 2 hours and the water is drained off completely. It is then washed with clean water and dried. 

Air floatation of grains is done to remove ergot, which is a field fungus. It can be removed by floating the grains in 20% saltwater, air floatation, or hand picking.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can cause gynecomastia?
questions.solution:
Gynecomastia can occur as an adverse effect of spironolactone.

Spironolactone decreases testosterone production, increases peripheral conversion of testosterone to estradiol, and displaces estradiol from its plasma-protein-binding sites.

Other drugs causing gynecomastia are:

Drugs causing gynecomastia:

  • Alcohol, marijuana, heroin
  • Antiretroviral therapy
  • Anabolic steroids
  • Digoxin
  • Risperidone
  • Ketoconazole
  • Spironolactone
  • α-methyldopa
  • Bromocriptine
  • Cimetidine
  • Phenytoin therapy
  • Androgens- testosterone and its esters (except dihydrotestosterone)

Note:

Clomiphene and tamoxifen are used mainly in reducing male gynecomastia.

questions.text: Identify the parasite whose microfilaria is given in the image below:
questions.solution:
Image showing sheathed microfilaria with a pointed tail, free of nuclei is suggestive of Wuchereria bancrofti. 

The female filarial worms, which belong to the phylum Nematoda, give birth to larvae known as microfilariae. Some of the microfilariae retain their egg membranes and are known as sheathed microfilariae. They can be further differentiated on the basis of the arrangement of nuclei in the tail.

Wuchereria bancrofti causes lymphatic filariasis and is the most common cause in India. Classical filariasis is due to obstruction of lymphatics by the adult worms resulting in lymph stasis. This leads to leakage of lymph into the tissues causing hard pitting (brawny) edema. It can present as acute adenolymphangitis, hydrocele, or elephantiasis which is shown below.

Investigations:

Demonstration of the microfilaria in peripheral blood, chylous urine, hydrocele fluid, etc is done.  The specimen of choice is peripheral blood. Night blood samples between 10 pm and 4 am are preferred. This is because the microfilaria shows nocturnal periodicity.

DEC provocation test: In this test, a small dose of DEC is given 20-50 minutes before sample collection so that the microfilaria appears in the blood even during the daytime. 

The image below shows the life cycle of Wuchereria bancrofti.

Related Pearl: Filarial worms and their morphology

questions.text: In which of the following tissues does gluconeogenesis take place?
questions.solution:
Liver and kidney are the two major locations where gluconeogenesis takes place.

During short periods of fasting, most of gluconeogenesis takes place in the liver, while the remaining takes place in the kidneys. However, during periods of prolonged fasting, the kidneys become a major site of gluconeogenesis.

Gluconeogenesis:

  • Gluconeogenesis is the process of synthesizing glucose or glycogen from non-carbohydrate precursors.
  • Gluconeogenesis occurs in cytosol and mitochondria of the liver and kidney.
  • Significant substrates are glucogenic amino acids, lactate, glycerol, and propionate.
  • Lactate generated in various tissues is transported to the liver and is converted to back to pyruvate and enters gluconeogenesis. This pathway is referred to as Cori’s cycle.
  • Glucose-alanine cycle is referred to as Cahill cycle.
  • Muscle cannot participate in gluconeogenesis since it lacks glucose-6-phosphatase.

Related Pearl: Irreversible enzymes in gluconeogenesis pathway

The enzymes can be remembered using the mnemonic Pathway Produces Fresh Glucose.

Pyruvate → Oxaloacetate

mitochondria

Activated by acetyl-CoA

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient presents with sudden bilateral swelling of lower limbs associated with diarrhea, dyspnea, and signs of cardiac failure. Mustard oil adulteration is suspected to be the cause. What is the toxin involved?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of epidemic dropsy. It is caused by the toxic compound sanguinarine, which is present in argemone oil extracted from argemone seeds. It is commonly used as an adulterant in mustard oil.

Epidemic dropsy results in sudden onset of swelling of lower limbs, diarrhea, and breathlessness. Some patients may develop glaucoma. It can lead to death due to cardiac failure.

Adulteration with argemone oil can be detected by the following tests:

  • Paper chromatography - most sensitive test
  • Nitric acid test

questions.text: A 55 year old postmenopausal woman came with complaints of irregular bleeding, breast tenderness, and abdominal pain. Abdomino-pelvic ultrasound revealed an adnexal mass. A biopsy from the mass revealed the following picture. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with biopsy showing gland-like structures, called Call–Exner bodies are suggestive of granulosa cell tumor.

Granulosa cell tumors are ovarian sex-cord stromal tumors made up of cells closely resembling the granulosa cells of the ovarian follicle. The majority of the time it is seen in post-menopausal women. 

These tumors are usually unilateral. In adult women, they may be associated with proliferative breast disease, postmenopausal irregular bleeding, breast tenderness, endometrial hyperplasia, and endometrial carcinoma. The presence of this tumor in prepubertal girls may lead to precocious puberty. Occasionally, granulosa cell tumors produce androgens, masculinizing the patient

The cut section is soft and has a yellowish reticular or trabecular appearance with interstitial hemorrhage. On microscopy, Call- Exner bodies are seen which are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material that resemble immature follicles.

Other options:

Option B: A yolk sac tumor/endodermal sinus tumor is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. Most of the yolk sac tumors have Schiller-Duval bodies and they are pathognomonic.

Option C: Krukenberg tumor is the carcinoma of the stomach that metastasize to the ovary. It is characterized by mucin-producing signet ring cells. 

Option D: Seminoma is the most common type of germ-cell tumor. The histological image shows sheets of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and a central nucleus, with a prominent nucleolus giving a fried-egg.

questions.text: Which of the following is the SI unit for the measurement of the amount of light reflected from a surface?
questions.solution:
The amount of light reflected from a surface is known as brightness or luminance. The SI unit for the measurement of brightness is candela/square meter.

questions.text: Which of these paraneoplastic syndromes is most commonly associated with small-cell carcinoma lung?

choices.text: Syndrome of inappropriate anti diuretic hormone

questions.solution:
Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) is associated with small cell carcinoma of the lung.

Other options:

Option A: Osteomalacia is associated with phosphaturic mesenchymal tumor

Option C: Polycythemia is seen in patients with renal carcinoma, cerebellar hemangioma, and hepatocellular carcinoma

Option D: Hypercalcemia is associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung, breast carcinoma, and renal carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Paraneoplastic dermatoses

questions.text: A 1-week-old lethargic neonate was brought to the pediatric OPD, he sleeps more than 3 hours after a feed, passes urine 7-8 times a day, and passes stools up to 5 times a day. He has a weight loss of 5% compared to his birth weight. Which of the following points is a sign of inadequate breastfeeding?

choices.text: Weight loss of 5% to birth weight
Sleeps more than 3 hours after a feed

questions.solution:
Lethargy(sleeping more than 2-3 hours after a feed) is an indicator of inadequate breastfeeding in an infant.

Indicators of inadequate breastfeeding in an infant:

  • Weight loss >7-10% of birth weight
  • Lethargy (sleeping longer than 2–3 hours)
  • Delayed stooling (Less than 4 times/day)
  • Decreased urine output (urinating less than 5–7 times/day)
  • Hypernatremic dehydration
  • Inconsolable crying and increased hunger

Insufficient milk intake could be due to insufficient milk production, failure of established breastfeeding, and health conditions in the infant that prevent proper breast stimulation.

Breastfed neonates usually feed 8–12 times a day, with a minimum of 8 times per day. However, the neonate should be breastfed on demand.

questions.text: Based on the X-ray of the hand given below, what is the likely age of the person?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows the appearance of pisiform(>10 years) but no fusion of base of 1st metacarpal(<17 years). Among the given options, the likely answer seems to be <17 years.

The base of all metacarpals appears at 2-3 years of age and fuse at 15-17 years of age. Since it is not fused in this case, the age is <17 years. If it has fused the likely age is >15 years 

Pisiform ossification center appears at 10-12 years of age. Since it is present in this case, the age of the child is more than 10 years. If it had not appeared, the likely age is <12 years.

Ossification Centres of Carpal Bones:

  • Capitate: 1-3 months
  • Hamate:  2-4 months
  • Triquetral: 2-3 years
  • Lunate: 3-4 years
  • Scaphoid: 4-6 years
  • Trapezium: 5-6 years
  • Trapezoid: 5-6 years
  • Pisiform: 10-12 years

The lower end of the radius appears at 2 years of age and fuses at 18-19 years of age. The lower end of the ulna appears at 5-6 years of age and fuses at 17-18 years of age. Here, both remain unfused indicating further that the age is likely to be less than 18.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient is posted for abscess drainage from the ischioanal fossa. While draining the abscess, the surgeon injures the nerve present in the Alcock's canal. Which nerve is injured in the given scenario?
questions.solution:
The nerve that is injured in the given scenario is the pudendal nerve. 

The pudendal nerve arises from the ventral divisions of the 2nd, 3rd and 4th ventral sacral rami. It originates in the pelvis and enters the gluteal region via the greater sciatic foramen close to its attachment at the ischial spine. It then passes through the lesser sciatic foramen into the pudendal (Alcock's) canal. In the pudendal canal, the pudendal nerve gives off the inferior rectal nerve, perineal nerve and dorsal nerve of the penis or clitoris.

Alcock's canal is an enclosed fascia along the lateral wall of the ischioanal fossa. Its contents include:

  • Internal pudendal artery
  • Internal pudendal vein
  • Pudendal nerve

Therefore, injury to the nerve in the Alcock's canal is to the pudendal nerve.

Pudendal neuralgia is a chronic pain syndrome that occurs due to damage or irritation to the pudendal nerve. It is characterized by perineal pain which gets aggravated by sitting. The common causes are prolonged sitting, repetitive hip flexions like in sports activities, direct trauma like falls, pelvic surgeries, and radiation therapy for pelvic cancers. It can be treated with nerve protection strategies, medications like gabapentin or amitriptyline, pudendal nerve blocks or decompression surgeries.

Note: Ischioanal fossa is a wedge-shaped space on either side of the anal canal in the anorectal triangle. It has a pad of fat. The boundaries include:

  • Anterior: Posterior border of the perineal membrane
  • Posterior: Gluteus maximus muscle, sacrotuberous ligament
  • Lateral: Ischial tuberosity, obturator internus
  • Medial: Sphincter ani externus, pelvic diaphragm (levator ani).

Clinical significance:

Ischioanal fossa provides a relatively bloodless field during resection of anal cancers, therefore it is an important surgical plane.

Other options:

Option A: Obturator nerve is a branch of the lumbar plexus that emerges near the L5 vertebra. It descends within the psoas major and then on the lateral wall of the pelvis before entering the obturator foramen to enter the thigh. It has no branches in the abdomen or pelvis.

Option B: Genitofemoral nerve arises from the L1 and L2. It pierces the psoas major and emerges out on the anterior surface. It descends and crosses obliquely behind the ureter and divides into genital and femoral branches. The genital branch passes through the inguinal canal and supplies the cremaster muscle and skin of the external genitalia. The femoral branch supplies the skin of the upper part of the femoral triangle. 

Option D: Accessory obturator nerve is formed from the L3 and L4. It emerges out along the medial border and travels on the posterior surface of the superior pubic ramus. It supplies the pectineus and hip joint.

questions.text: Following an earthquake, the building codes were changed to earthquake-resistant buildings. Which of the following step of disaster management does this fall under?
questions.solution:
Changing the building codes to earthquake-resistant buildings are part of disaster mitigation.

Disaster mitigation measures aim to reduce the vulnerability of the system. It complements disaster preparedness and response activities and includes measures taken to lessen the likely effects of emergencies. Some of these measures are:

  • Flood mitigation
  • Land-use planning
  • Improved building codes
  • Reduction and protection of vulnerable populations or structures.

Other options:

Option A - Disaster response includes activities such as rescue and first aid, field care, triage and tagging that form a part of the emergency care needed in the first few hours after a disaster.

Option B - Disaster reconstruction is a part of the recovery phase after a disaster.

Option C - Disaster rehabilitation refers to measures that lead to the restoration of pre-disaster conditions. These measures include water supply restoration, food safety, basic sanitation, personal hygiene, and vector control.

The disaster management cycle is given below:

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true concerning the anatomy of the breast?

choices.text: Outer inner quadrant contains maximum breast tissue
Ligaments of cooper are found only in lower quadrants
Tail of Spence extends across anterior axillary fold

questions.solution:
The tail of Spence extends across the anterior axillary fold and is a small extension of the upper lateral quadrant of the breast.

The breast lies in the superficial fascia of the pectoral region. It is divided into four quadrants, i.e. upper medial, upper lateral, lower medial and lower lateral. 

Vertically, it extends from the second to the sixth ribs. Horizontally, it extends from the lateral border of the sternum to the midaxillary line. A small extension of the upper lateral quadrant, called the axillary tail of Spence, passes through an opening in the deep fascia and lies in the axilla. The opening is called the foramen of Langer. 

The breast lies on the deep pectoral fascia covering the pectoralis major and serratus anterior superiorly, the external abdominal oblique and its aponeurosis inferiorly, and the clavipectoral fascia laterally. Fibrous strands or sheets consisting of condensations of connective tissue extend between the posterior lamina of the superficial fascia and the dermis. These suspensory ligaments (retinacula or Cooper’s ligaments) are often well-developed in the superior parts of the breast and support the breast tissue, helping to minimize drooping.

The breasts normally comprise up to 20 discrete lobes that contain ductal-glandular tissue consisting of branching ducts and terminal secretory lobules in a connective tissue stroma. Each lobe is derived by branching from one central lactiferous duct in the nipple. The terminal duct lobular unit (TDLU or lobule) is the functional milk secretory component of the breast. 

The upper outer quadrant of the breast contains a greater volume of tissue than the other quadrants. This is the reason for the majority of the carcinomas arising in the upper outer quadrant.

The breast lies on the deep pectoral fascia covering the pectoralis major and serratus anterior superiorly, the external abdominal oblique and its aponeurosis inferiorly, and the clavipectoral fascia laterally. Fibrous strands or sheets consisting of condensations of connective tissue extend between the posterior lamina of the superficial fascia and the dermis. These suspensory ligaments (retinacula or Cooper’s ligaments) are often well-developed in the superior parts of the breast and support the breast tissue, helping to minimize drooping.

The breasts normally comprise up to 20 discrete lobes that contain ductal-glandular tissue consisting of branching ducts and terminal secretory lobules in a connective tissue stroma. Each lobe is derived by branching from one central lactiferous duct in the nipple. The terminal duct lobular unit (TDLU or lobule) is the functional milk secretory component of the breast. 

The upper outer quadrant of the breast contains a greater volume of tissue than the other quadrants. This is the reason for the majority of the carcinomas arising in the upper outer quadrant.

questions.text: A concerned mother brings her baby to the OPD saying that the baby defecates shortly after every meal. Which of the following GIT hormones amplify this response?
questions.solution:
The scenario given in the question is a classic description of the gastrocolic reflex. Gastrin amplifies the gastrocolic reflex.

Distension of the stomach and digestive byproducts in the small intestine activate afferents to the prevertebral sympathetic ganglia. This results in stimulation of the colon and an urge to defecate. This is known as the gastrocolic reflex. This reflex is amplified by the action of gastrin.

GIT reflexes which are mediated by prevertebral sympathetic ganglia include:

  • Gastrocolic reflex
  • Enterogastric reflex → signals from the colon and small intestine inhibit stomach motility and secretion
  • Colonoileal reflex → signals from the colon to inhibit the emptying of ileal contents into the colon

GIT reflexes which are mediated by the brain stem and spinal cord include:

  • Pain reflexes that cause inhibition of the whole gastrointestinal tract
  • Long-distance vagal reflexes regulating gastric motor and secretory activity
  • Defecation reflex → Distension of the rectum and colon results in powerful contractions of the rectum, colon, and abdominal wall which are required for defecation.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented to the emergency department with right hemiplegia following a cerebrovascular accident. Cranial nerve examination reveals deviation of the tongue to the paralyzed side on protrusion. Identify the cranial nerve affected in this patient.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with right-sided hemiplegia and tongue deviation to the paralyzed side on protrusion is suggestive of hypoglossal nerve injury. In the given image, the nerve labeled as '3' is the hypoglossal nerve.

The hypoglossal nerve (XII cranial nerve) supplies the muscles of the tongue. It leaves the cranial cavity through the hypoglossal canal (anterior condylar canal). It supplies 3 extrinsic muscles (all excluding palatoglossus) and all 4 intrinsic muscles of the tongue.

​​The hypoglossal nerve is tested clinically by asking the patient to protrude tongue. Normally, the tongue protrudes straight forward. If the nerve is paralyzed, the tongue deviates to the paralyzed side.

The image below shows location the cranial nerves in relation to the brainstem:


Other options:

Option A: The oculomotor nerve is a purely motor nerve arising from two nuclei: the main motor nucleus and the accessory parasympathetic nucleus. The main nucleus lies at the level of the superior colliculus of the midbrain. The accessory parasympathetic nucleus (Edinger-Westphal nucleus) is situated posterior to the main nucleus. 

Option B: Facial Nerve arises from the brainstem at the pontomedullary junction. The facial colliculus is present on the floor of the fourth ventricle at the level of the lower pontine tegmentum. This colliculus contains the abducens nerve nucleus and the fibers of the facial nerve, which form the internal genu as they travel around the abducens nerve nucleus.

Option D: The trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) arises from the substance of pons and is responsible for sensory input from the face, as well as motor functions such as chewing. Its sensory pathway involves three branches: the ophthalmic (V1), maxillary (V2), and mandibular (V3) divisions.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man suffered a traumatic brain injury after a road traffic accident in which he fell from his motorcycle. He was brought to the emergency department where he was stabilized and a CT scan was performed which showed extensive damage to the medial undersides of both occipital lobes and the inferior medioventral surfaces of the temporal lobes. When he meets his family, which among the following is likely to happen?

choices.text: Unable to understand what they are saying

questions.solution:
Lesions to the medial underside of both occipital lobes and the inferior medioventral surfaces of the temporal lobes cause prosopagnosia, which is the inability to identify faces.

The right inferior temporal lobe in right-handed individuals represents the storage and recognition of faces. Damage to this area can cause prosopagnosia. Patients with prosopagnosia can recognize people by their voices and also show autonomic responses when they see familiar faces. The left hemisphere is also involved, but the right hemisphere plays a major role.

Other options:

Option A: The inability to understand is seen in Wernicke's aphasia. The patient is not able to comprehend the meaning of spoken or written words. The speech is full of jargon and neologisms that do not make sense. It occurs due to a lesion in the superior temporal gyrus.

Option B: The inability to recognize familiar voices is called phonagnosia. It is seen after damage to the inferior and lateral parietal regions of the right hemisphere.

Option D: Difficulty in forming words(verbal or written) is seen in Broca's aphasia or motor aphasia. This occurs as a result of a lesion in Broca's area in the frontal lobe. Affected individuals have slow speech.

questions.text: Oral hairy leukoplakia is associated with which of the following infections?
questions.solution:
Oral hairy leukoplakia (OHL) is due to the reactivation of Epstein Barr Virus (EBV) infection and usually occurs in association with immunodeficiency due to HIV infection.

Oral hairy leukoplakia in HIV-infected patients presents with white corrugated plaque over the lateral border of the tongue, which cannot be rubbed off. 

Other conditions associated with EBV infection are

  • Glandular fever: fever, pharyngitis, and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Rash triggered by Ampicillin
  • Burkitt's Lymphoma
  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma
  • EBV‐associated lymphoproliferative disease
  • Age‐related EBV‐associated B‐cell lymphoma

questions.text: A newborn assessed 5 minutes after birth is found to have a  heart rate of 90 beats/min and irregular respiration. The baby coughed on inserting a nasal catheter and was moving all his limbs actively. The body was pink with blue extremities. What is the Apgar score in this newborn?
questions.solution:
The Apgar score in this newborn is 7.

The Apgar score is a systematic way of assessing the infant after birth at 1 and 5 minutes of life. It gives a maximum score of 10 that indicates the newborn is in the best possible condition.

Scores between 0-3 require immediate resuscitation. Changes in the Apgar scores denote the response of the infant to resuscitation. If the score at 5 minutes remains less than 7, the infant should be assessed again every 5 minutes for the next 20 minutes.

The individual scores for all parameters given in the given clinical scenario are:

  • Appearance: Body is pink with blue extremities = 1
  • Pulse: 90 beats/min = 1
  • Grimace: Coughs on nasal catheter insertion = 2
  • Active motion: Moves all the limbs actively = 2
  • Respiratory effort - Irregular respiration = 1

Thus the total score in this baby is 7. 

Causes for low Apgar score are:

  • Fetal distress
  • Prematurity
  • Drugs like analgesics, narcotics, sedatives, magnesium sulfate
  • Acute cerebral trauma
  • Precipitous delivery
  • Airway obstruction (choanal atresia)  
  • Congenital pneumonia or sepsis
  • Hemorrhage- hypovolemia

False-negative Apgar score is seen in maternal acidosis and high fetal catecholamine levels.

questions.text: According to myogenic hypothesis of renal autoregulation the afferent arterioles contract in response to stretch-induced by______
questions.solution:
The afferent arterioles contract in response to stretch-induced by opening of calcium channels. The mechanism is called Myogenic autoregulation of renal blood flow and GFR. 

Stretch of the vascular wall allows increased movement of calcium ions from the extracellular fluid into the cells, causing them to contract. This contraction prevents excessive stretch of the vessel. This prevents excessive increase of renal blood flow and GFR by raising vascular resistance.

This mechanism may be more important in protecting the kidney from hypertension-induced injury.

Autoregulation has two main mechanisms:

  • Metabolic mechanism: Tissues produce vasodilatory metabolites that regulate flow e.g., adenosine, prostaglandins, NO, CO2, H+ and K+
  • Myogenic mechanism

questions.text: Which of the following public health centers do First Referral Units (FRUs) and non-FRUs belong to?
questions.solution:
First Referral Units (FRUs) and non-FRUs belong to the Community Health Centers (CHCs). 

The Indian Public Health Standards (IPHS) guidelines are a code of standards for uniformity in health facilities in the Indian public health system, under the National Health Mission (NHM), Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW), India. It aims to provide guidance on the infrastructure, human resources, drugs, diagnostics, equipment, quality, and governance requirements for delivering health services at all levels of facilities in the system.

The 2022 edition of IPHS mainly concentrates on comprehensive primary health care, increasing the human workforce, decentralized access to healthcare, and better implementation of universal health coverage.

Related Pearl: Levels of Healthcare System in India

Related Pearl: Elements and Principles of Primary Health Care

A. Elements of Primary Health Care

(Mnemonic: ELEMENTS)

  • Education about health problems and their prevention and control
  • Locally endemic diseases – prevention and control
  • Essential drugs
  • Maternal and child health care
  • Expanded programme of immunization against vaccine preventable diseases
  • Nutrition and proper food supply
  • Treatment of common diseases and injuries
  • Safe water and sanitation

B. Principles/Pillars of Primary Health Care

  • Equitable distribution
  • Community participation
  • Intersectoral coordination
  • Appropriate technology

questions.text: A young girl was rushed to the emergency room in a delirious state. Her parents reported her to have consumed a wild fruit as shown below while on a camping trip. On examination, photophobia, staggering gait, flushing, and dry mucous membranes are noticed. The pupils are bilaterally dilated. Which of the following plant poisons she may have consumed?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing cherry-like fruit is suggestive that the plant poison the patient may have consumed is Atropa belladonna. 

Atropa belladonna is a deliriant poison that acts by inhibiting the muscarinic effects of acetylcholine. All the parts of the plants are toxic. The active principle is 1-hyoscyamine.

Clinical manifestations of Atropa belladonna poisoning include: 

  • Fever, flushing, rash
  • Neurological symptoms - delirium, slurred speech, headache, choreoathetosis, myoclonus, visual and auditory hallucinations, convulsions and coma
  • Eye symptoms - photophobia, blurred vision, dilated pupils poorly reactive to light
  • Cardiovascular symptoms - arrhythmia, tachycardia, hypertension
  • Gastrointestinal symptoms - severely dry mouth and throat, decreased bowel sounds, constipation, ileus
  • Renal symptoms - urinary retention

Anticholinergic symptoms include tachycardia, hypertension, flushing, dry mouth, mydriasis and urinary retention. 

Treatment - Conservative management with gastric lavage with activated charcoal. Benzodiazepines are used to control agitation and delirium. Physostigmine is a specific antidote, that should be given in cases of tachycardia, coma and respiratory arrest.

Other options - 

Option A - Datura poisoning also presents with similar symptoms, but the image given is not of datura stramonium.

Option B - Nicotiana tabacum is a cardiac poison, all parts of the plant are poisonous except the ripe seeds. Acute poisoning results in burning sensation, abdominal pain, hypersalivation, tachycardia, hypotension, and respiratory depression.

Option C - Ricinus poisoning leads to symptoms such as the burning of oral mucosa, salivation, nausea, vomiting, severe abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhoea. It may also cause drowsiness, convulsions, delirium, and death. The entire plant is poisonous, but seeds are the most toxic and toxic principle is toxalbumin ricin which acts by blocking protein synthesis.

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition shown in the graph.
questions.solution:
The above graph is called a 'Lineweaver-Burk plot' or 'double reciprocal' plot and it represents noncompetitive inhibition.

Non-competitive inhibition: When the substrate and the inhibitor are chemically not similar and have different shapes, the inhibitor binds away from the active site, i.e., at the allosteric site. This type of inhibition is known as non-competitive inhibition.

In non-competitive inhibition,

  • Vmax decreases.(1/Vmax increases)
  • Km remains constant.

In a Lineweaver-Burk Plot, the addition of a non-competitive inhibitor causes plots with the same x-intercept (Km is unaffected) but different slopes and y-intercepts.

Competitive inhibition - Here, the inhibitor is a structural analog of the substrate. Inhibitor molecules are competing with the normal substrate molecules for binding to the active site of the enzyme. Here Vmax is unchanged (same y-intercept), and Km is increased (− 1/Km moves closer to zero from a negative value).

Uncompetitive inhibition  - Here, the inhibitor does not have any affinity for the free enzyme. The inhibitor binds to the enzyme-substrate complex, but not to the free enzyme. Here, both Vmax and Km are decreased.

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Reversible inhibitors are of two types:

  • Competitive inhibitors
  • Non-Competitive inhibitors

Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by Malonate

Pyruvate kinase is inhibited by alanine

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically similar & have same shape

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically not similar & have different shape

Inhibitor binds to active site

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax remains constant

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

Km remains constant

questions.text: A patient came to OPD with complaints of passing loose bulky stools that were associated with abdominal pain for the past 2 weeks. The stool examination shows the following organism. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and an image showing a pear-shaped / pyriform-shaped trophozoite is suggestive of giardiasis caused by Giardia lamblia.

Giardia lamblia, also called Giardia duodenalis, is the causative agent of giardiasis. It is a common pathogenic protozoan found in the duodenum and jejunum of humans.

Infection occurs by the ingestion of mature cysts in contaminated water and food. and may also be transmitted by the faecal-oral route.

It is weakly pathogenic in humans. Hence, giardiasis usually occurs in immunosuppressed, agammaglobulinemia, or malnourished individuals.

Clinical features:

  • Diarrhoea 
  • Fat malabsorption
  • Dull epigastric pain
  • Belching and flatulence
  • Iron deficiency and growth stunting.
  • The stool will have excess mucus and fat but no blood.

Detection of antigens by ELISA is more sensitive and specific than microscopy. Entero test /string test is also used in the diagnosis.

Histopathology of the duodenum reveals several heart-shaped or pear-shaped trophozoites. The trophozoite is heart-shaped or pyriform-shaped with 2 equally sized nuclei and 4 pairs of flagella. It exhibits slow oscillating motility that resembles falling leaf motility. 

Other options:

Isospora belli is a coccidian parasite that can cause protracted diarrhea in immunocompromised patients. The oocyst is not easily seen on stool-wet mounts. It may be visible after stool concentration and staining with acid-fast stain, as shown below.

Cryptosporidium parvum, commonly causes diarrhea in immunocompromised individuals. The oocysts in the stool can be visualized by modified Ziehl-Neelsen staining. It appears as red acid-fast spheres. It can also be used for specimens such as sputum and bronchial wash. The image given below demonstrates uniformly acid-fast oocysts of Cryptosporidium parvum.

Trichomonas vaginalis is found in the genital tract. The image given below shows the trophozoite of Trichomonas vaginalis.

questions.text: Insulin inhibits which of the following lipase enzymes?
questions.solution:
Insulin has an inhibitory effect on lipolytic hormones like hormone sensitive lipase (HSL). In adipose tissues, the stored triglycerides are broken down (lipolysis) by hormone sensitive lipase (HSL) into free fatty acids (FFAs). Insulin inhibits HSL and thus reduces the release of FFAs and also glycerol.

In diabetic patients, low insulin level corresponds to an increase in HSL activity, promoting the breakdown of lipids and release of FFAs from adipose tissue. Hormone-sensitive lipase activity is accelerated by hormones like epinephrine, norepinephrine, glucagon, ACTH, TSH, GH, ADH, and Melanocyte stimulating hormones (MSH).

Insulin induces the activity of lipoprotein lipase (LPL) which is present on the walls of capillaries. LPL promotes hydrolysis of TGs and degradation of VLDL and chylomicrons. In diabetes, low insulin leads to decreased LPL activity resulting in increased VLDL and TGs levels.

Well-fed state (Insulin) During fasting (Glucagon)
Lipogenesis increased Lipogenesis inhibited
Lipolysis inhibited Lipolysis increased
Insulin inhibits HS-lipase Glucagon activates HS-lipase
Lipoprotein lipase active Lipoprotein lipase inactive

Effects of insulin on various tissues:

Tissue Increases Decreases
Adipose tissue Increased glucose entry
Increased fatty acid synthesis
Increased glycerol phosphate synthesis
Increased triglycerides deposition
Activation of lipoprotein lipase
Increased K+ uptake		 Inhibition of hormone-sensitive lipase
Muscle Increased glucose entry
Increased glycogen synthesis
Increased amino acid uptake
Increased protein synthesis in ribosome
Increase ketone uptake
Increase K+ uptake

Decrease protein catabolism

Decrease  release of glucogenic amino acids
Liver Increased protein synthesis
Increased lipid synthesis
Increased glycogen synthesis & glycolysis

Decrease ketogenesis

Decreased glucose output due to decreased gluconeogenesis
General Increased cell growth

questions.text: The transport of acyl-CoA for oxidation using a shuttle involves the formation of intermediate ______.
questions.solution:
The transport of acyl-CoA(active form of fatty acid) for oxidation inside the mitochondria using a shuttle involves the formation of intermediate acyl-carnitine.

The enzyme CPT-1 (Carnitine palmitoyl transferase-I), present on the outer mitochondrial membrane catalyzes the reaction.

Inner  mitochondrial membrane

Help Acylcarnitine to penetrate the inner membrane

Inner  mitochondrial membrane

questions.text: An elderly tuberculosis patient on treatment is non-compliant to initial therapy. Drug susceptibility showed resistance to rifampicin and isoniazid. He was started with the next-line drug that inhibits mycobacterial ATP synthesis. Which of the following can be the newly given drug?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the drug that inhibits mycobacterial ATP synthesis is bedaquiline.

Bedaquiline targets subunit c of the ATP synthase of M. tuberculosis. This results in inhibition of the proton pump activity of the ATP synthase and causes a failure in the bacillary energy metabolism.

Regimen for MDR TB:

400 mg daily for 2 weeks followed by 200 mg three times a day thereafter.

Other options:

Option A: Cycloserine inhibits alanine racemase that converts L-alanine to D-alanine. This stops the reactions in which D-alanine is incorporated into mycobacterial bacterial cell wall synthesis. 

Option B: Ethioinamide inhibits mycobacterial growth by inhibiting the activity of the enoyl-ACP reductase of fatty acid synthase II which is an inhA gene product. Isoniazid inhibits the same enzyme. 

Option D- Pretomanid is used in extensively drug-resistant and multi-drug-resistant TB. It inhibits mycolic acids and proteins synthesis of M. tuberculosis and in non-replicating persistent bacilli, they create reactive nitrogen species which then increases the killing of the bacterium by innate immunity.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is being evaluated for hematuria.  Histopathology showed mesangial widening and endocapillary proliferation. The following finding is seen on immunofluorescence. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, histopathology findings of mesangial widening and endocapillary proliferation, as well as immunofluorescence showing mesangial deposits are suggestive of IgA nephropathy (Berger's disease).

It is the most common type of glomerulonephritis in adults. It is characterized by recurrent hematuria/ nephritic syndrome and the presence of prominent IgA deposits in the mesangium. 

The systemic variant of IgA nephropathy is associated with Henoch–Schönlein purpura. It is a disorder of children which presents with similar renal manifestations with characteristic IgA deposits in the mesangium in about one-third of the patients.

Related Pearl: Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes

 

Nephrotic Syndrome

Nephritic Syndrome (Glomerulonephritis)

Primary pathology

Damage and dysfunction of glomerular filtration barrier, causing significant leakage of plasma proteins without much glomerular inflammation

Significant inflammatory injury of the glomerulus resulting in passage of RBCs, inflammatory cells & plasma proteins

The principal site of glomerular injury

 Visceral epithelial cell (Podocyte) Endothelial cells, glomerular basement membrane (GBM), Mesangial cells, Parietal epithelial cells (>Crescents)

Clinical features

Hallmark:

Heavy Proteinuria: 3.5 g/24 h or Urine protein:creatinine ratio >3) 

Hypoalbuminemia, 

Edema

Lipiduria, Hyperlipidemia

Microscopic hematuria

Hypertension

Hypercoagulability                                                    

Hallmark:

Hematuria (RBC casts/dysmorphic RBCs)

Varying degrees of proteinuria and pyuria

Renal dysfunction

Hypertension

Associated Glomerular pathology

Minimal change disease (Primary and secondary)

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Primary and secondary)

Membranous-nephropathy (Primary and secondary)

Diabetic nephropathy

Amyloidosis

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (crescentic)

IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

Alport syndrome

These syndromes, however, are not mutually exclusive. Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythromytosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: A laborer's second child is brought to the OPD with a swollen belly and dull face. He has been fed rice water (rice milk) in his diet mostly. On investigations, the child is found to have low serum protein and low albumin. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with a swollen belly, dull face with hypoproteinemia along with poor diet history suggests the diagnosis of kwashiorkor. 

Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) characterized by edema and apathy. In edematous malnutrition, the initial appearance of edema is commonly observed in the feet and lower legs, progressing into generalized edema affecting the hands, arms, and face. The skin over the swollen areas may show dark, crackled, peeling patches (flaky paint dermatosis) with pale skin underneath, making it susceptible to infections. 

There may be sparse and easily pluckable hair. Hepatomegaly with fatty infiltration is a common finding. Associated symptoms of misery, apathy, and loss of appetite are seen in children with edema. 

Other options: 

Option B: Marasmus is a severe form of wasting characterized by significant loss of fat and muscle tissue as the body utilizes these resources for energy. It is often triggered by acute starvation or illness in individuals with borderline nutritional status. 

Option C: Indian childhood cirrhosis (ICC) is a chronic liver disease that affects infants and young children. Common symptoms include jaundice, pruritus, lethargy, and hepatosplenomegaly. The disease progresses rapidly, leading to the development of cirrhosis. 

Option D: Kawasaki disease (KD) is a systemic inflammatory disorder with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It presents with fever, rash, conjunctivitis,  and cervical lymph node enlargement.

questions.text: A person working in an industry for a long time developed progressive breathlessness. The histopathological image of his lung biopsy is given below. Which industry was he most likely working in?
questions.solution:
From the clinical history of progressive breathlessness and the histopathological image showing asbestos bodies, ferruginous bodies, and fibrosis, the patient is most likely working in the asbestos industry.

Asbestosis occurs due to the inhalation of crystalline hydrated silicates (asbestos). It is characterized by diffuse parenchymal interstitial fibrosis. It usually begins in the lower lobes of the lungs and may present with dyspnoea and cough, usually after 20-30 years of exposure. Other asbestos-related diseases include pleural plaques, recurrent pleural effusions, lung carcinoma, and mesothelioma.

Asbestos bodies are a hallmark finding. They appear as golden brown, fusiform, or beaded rods. These are formed when the asbestos fibers are phagocytosed by the macrophages and are coated by iron-containing proteinaceous material derived from phagocyte ferritin. Similar iron-protein complexes coat other inorganic particulates other than asbestos which are termed as ferruginous bodies.

The image below shows asbestos bodies.

Other options:

Option A: Silicosis is due to the inhalation of crystalline silicon dioxide (silica) as seen in individuals employed in sandblasting or rock mining. Microscopy reveals coalescent nodules of whorled collagen fibers surrounded by a peripheral zone of silica-laden macrophages (shown below).

 

Option C: Anthracosis/coal workers' pneumoconiosis is a pulmonary condition seen in coal miners. Microscopic features consist of coal-laden macrophages, black pigment, and dense collagenous interstitial fibrosis. 

The image below shows anthracosis - black pigment engulfed within macrophages as well as in the form of deposits.

 

Option D: Cotton dust causes byssinosis and can induce occupational asthma.

questions.text: Identify the graph given below
questions.solution:
The graph shows a propagated epidemic.

A propagated epidemic is one in which there is a rise and fall in the number of cases multiple times with a gradual fall in cases overall. It occurs in infectious diseases where there is person-to-person transmission. Peaks repeat when there is a spread of infection to a different set of susceptible individuals. It continues till there are no more susceptible individuals or the chances of exposure to the disease or vector come down. It is common in communities where there are large aggregates of susceptible populations or there is a continuous supply of suseptible population by birth or immigration.

Related Pearl: Epidemics and its Types

Epidemics and its Types

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy.

Types

Common source epidemics

  • Single exposure or 'point source' epidemics
  • Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated epidemics

  • Person to person
  • Arthropod vector
  • Animal reservoir

Slow or modern epidemics

  • Non-communicable diseases

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the structural organization of proteins?

choices.text: Primary, secondary and tertiary structures are destroyed by denaturation
Secondary structure is stabilized by disulphide bonds
Secondary and tertiary structure depends upon amino acid sequence

questions.solution:
The tertiary structure is three dimensional is the right answer among the given options. Secondary, tertiary, and quaternary structures are three-dimensional.
 
Structural organization of proteins:

Primary: a linear sequence of amino acids in the polypeptide chain

Secondary: Folded and geometrically ordered units of short segments of polypeptides; example alpha helix, beta-pleated sheets, loops, and bends

Tertiary: Secondary structures arranged into larger functional units

Quaternary: Different types of polypeptides arranged in a spatial manner

Other options

Option B: Protein denaturation results in the unfolding and disorganization of the secondary and tertiary structures without the hydrolysis of peptide bonds, which form the primary structure.

Option C: Hydrogen bond and Van der Waals interactions are involved in the stabilization of secondary structure (helix). Disulfide bonds stabilize the tertiary structure of proteins.

Option D: Primary structure depends upon the amino acid sequence.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a history of blunt trauma to the pelvis was diagnosed with urethral rupture. Imaging revealed extravasation of the urine into the superficial perineal pouch. The attachment of which ​of the following fascia prevents extravasation into the thigh and anal triangle?
questions.solution:
Colle's fascia prevents the extravasation of the urine from spreading into the thigh and anal triangle. 

Scarpa's fascia is continuous with the superficial fascia of the scrotum and becomes the Colles' fascia. In women, it continues into the labia majora and is continuous with the fascia of the perineum. Colle's fascia has the following attachments:

  • Posterior - perineal membrane. It prevents the extravasation of fluids such as blood, pus, or urine into the anal triangle. 
  • Lateral - ischiopubic rami and fascia lata along Holden's line. This line extends from the pubic tubercle laterally for 8 cm. It prevents the extravasation of fluids into the thigh. 

Option A: Camper's fascia is the superficial fatty layer of the superficial fascia of the abdomen.

Option B: Scarpa's fascia is the deep membranous layer of the superficial fascia of the abdomen.

Option C: Buck's fascia is the deep fascia of the penis 

Clinical significance:

When a urethral injury occurs, urine can extravasate into the superficial perineal pouch, penis, scrotum, labia majora and the anterior abdominal wall.

questions.text: Which among the following does the graph given below depict?
questions.solution:
The graph given above depicts the Haldane effect.

The Haldane effect occurs when the partial pressure of O2 is higher as in the lungs.

Binding of O2 with hemoglobin tends to displace CO2 from hemoglobin. This is because the binding of O2 to the hemoglobin makes it a stronger acid. This causes the carbaminohemoglobin to dissociate and releases the CO2 from the hemoglobin. CO2 is then eliminated from the lungs.

In the given graph, when the partial pressure of O2 is higher ( 100 mmHg), as in capillaries of lungs, the CO2 dissociation curve shifts to the right (the amount of CO2 in the blood decreases, as it is expired out).

Thus, the Haldane effect approximately doubles the amount of CO2 eliminated from the blood in the lungs and approximately doubles the pickup of CO2 from the tissues.

 

Other options:

  • Option A: Bohr effect: Decrease in the binding of O2 to hemoglobin (Shift of O2 dissociation curve to the right) in the presence of raised CO2 and low PH. This enhances O2-hemoglobin binding in the lungs and decreases O2 binding in the tissues. 
  • Option B: Henry's Law in Respiration: The amount of oxygen that dissolves into the bloodstream is directly proportional to the partial pressure of oxygen in alveolar air.
  • Option D: Boyle's Law: The pressure of a fixed mass of gas is inversely proportional to its volume if its temperature is kept constant.

questions.text: Which of the marked structures below does not have the mesoderm layer?
questions.solution:
The marked structure 'C' represents the buccopharyngeal membrane, which lacks the mesodermal layer but is composed of an amalgamation of the ectodermal and endodermal layers.

The buccopharyngeal membrane, which is the demarcation between ectoderm and endoderm disappears by 4th week of development. The ectodermal and endodermal layers then become continuous with each other. 

The intraembryonic mesoderm is absent in the following regions, that remain bilaminar throughout life :

  • Prochordal plate: This later develops into the buccopharyngeal membrane
  • Cloacal membrane: This later develops into the anal and urogenital membranes.
  • In the midline caudal to the prochordal plate, the region is occupied by the notochord.

questions.text: In a case-control study, lung compliance of two different groups (B and C) was studied against the control group (A) and recorded as shown in the graph below. Which of the following cases, likely represents the groups B and C, respectively?

choices.text: Pulmonary emphysema and normal ageing lung
Alveolar oedema and normal ageing lung

questions.solution:
Graphs B and C correspond to increased and decreased compliance respectively. Among the given options, pulmonary emphysema is associated with increased compliance, and pulmonary fibrosis is associated with decreased compliance.

Compliance is defined as a change in lung volume per unit change in surrounding pressure. It is expressed as:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP.

The graph shown below explains the change in volume of the lung, as the intrapleural pressure increases. 

Here the compliance of B>A>C.

Compliance is increased in normal ageing lungs and pulmonary emphysema due to decreased elastic recoil of lungs (a tendency of the lungs to become less stretched). 

Compliance is decreased in pulmonary fibrosis, alveolar oedema, unventilated lungs due to alveoli being prevented from getting inflated.

Related Pearl: Lung Compliance

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in the surrounding pressure.

It is represented by the formula:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP

Factors Affecting Compliance

  • Lung volume: smaller the lungs, smaller is the compliance
  • For a given lung size, the compliance becomes less at extremes of lung volume
  • Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than during inflation
  • If the surface tension is more, compliance is less
  • Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air.

Compliance is decreased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis: Due to increased fibrous tissue in the lung, making it less elastic, and thus less expandable.
  • Alveolar edema, which prevents the expansion of some alveoli.
  • If lung remains unventilated for a long time, in a low volume lung, due to atelectasis (collapse) of lung units or increased surface tension.
  • Increased pulmonary venous pressure.

Compliance is increased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary emphysema
  • Normal aging lung

questions.text: What is the embryological basis of the developmental defect shown in the image below?

choices.text: Failure in closure of anterior neuropore of neural tube
Failure in closure of posterior neuropore of neural tube
Failure in closure of complete neural tube
Failure in closure of caudal neuropore of neural tube

questions.solution:
The image shows anencephaly.

Failure of the anterior end (cranial end) of the neural tube to close is known as exencephaly. As a result of this, the skull vault does not form. This leaves the malformed brain exposed. The exposed brain tissue degenerates, leaving a mass of necrotic tissue. This defect with the absence of a major portion of the brain, skull, and scalp is known as anencephaly. The brain stem remains intact.

In some cases, the closure defect of the neural tube extends caudally, and the spinal cord is affected. This condition is known as craniorachischisis, where there is anencephaly plus a large defect involving the spine. 

Neurulation refers to the formation of the neural tube from the neural plate. The neural tube gives rise to the central nervous system. 

Steps of neurulation

  • The notochord induces the overlying ectoderm to thicken and form the neural plate.
  • The neural plate lengthens and the lateral edges elevate to form the neural folds, and the mid-region gets depressed to form the neural groove.
  • The neural folds approach each and fuse in the midline in a craniocaudal direction to form a tube-like structure called the neural tube.
  • The anterior opening of the neural tube (cranial neuropore) closes by day 25 and the posterior opening (caudal neuropore) closes by day 28.
  • The neural tube becomes the central nervous system.

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic patient presented with complaints of fever, cough, and hemoptysis for a few weeks. On staining his sputum, gram-negative bacilli with the typical safety pin appearance were identified. Culture on Ashdown medium showed wrinkled, purple colonies. Which of the following could be the possible causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Whitmore's disease or melioidosis caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei.

Infection with B. pseudomallei is acquired by contamination of abrasion wounds with soil and water containing the bacilli. Patients with underlying diseases like diabetes mellitus have an increased risk of acquiring the infection.

Melioidosis can be of two types:

  • Acute - It causes acute pneumonia with upper lobe infiltrates or severe necrotizing disease. It can also mimic tuberculosis with fever, cough, and hemoptysis. It may lead to septicemia. Acute cases have a high case fatality rate. 
  • Chronic - It can lead to the development of multiple caseous or suppurative foci, with skin and subcutaneous abscesses. These can lead to lymphangitis and lymphadenopathy. It may involve bones and other internal organs.

On microscopy, gram-negative bacilli with a typical bipolar safety-pin appearance (as shown below) is seen.

The image below shows dry purple wrinkled colonies of B. pseudomallei cultured in Ashdown medium. 

Treatment is divided into two stages: an intensive phase of 2 weeks of therapy with ceftazidime (drug of choice) or a carbapenem, followed by 12 weeks of oral cotrimoxazole to eradicate the organism and prevent relapse.

Option B: Burkholderia mallei causes glanders disease. It is a gram-negative, irregularly staining bacillus with a beaded appearance. It is usually an equine infection. Human infection is possible and is usually occupational, found among veterinarians and persons working with/caring for horses.

Option C: Burkholderia cepacia is an opportunist pathogen, usually seen in cases of cystic fibrosis or chronic granulomatous disease. It causes a rapidly fatal syndrome of respiratory distress and septicemia (cepacia syndrome) in cystic fibrosis patients.

Option D: Paraburkholderia species do not cause human infection. They are beneficial to plants.

questions.text:
Match the following weapons with their possible injury type:
A. Axe 1. Incised wound
B. RTA 2. Tram track bruise
C. Blade 3. Grazed abrasion
D. Lathi 4. Chop wound
questions.solution:
For the above-given weapons, possible injury type is matched as under:

A. Axe 4. Chop wounds
B. RTA 3. Graze abrasions
C. Blade 1. Incised wound
D. Lathi 2. Tram track bruise

Mechanism of injury with the above weapons

Axe - it is a heavy weapon that may or may not be sharpened. Injury is produced by chopping action of the weapon and it may be in a spectrum of an incised wound to laceration depending upon the sharpness of the blade.

RTA - rubbing of epidermis tangential to a rough or hard surface gives rise to graze abrasion also called brush burn. It can occur in an RTA after a pedestrian is being hit by a vehicle and the victim is slid/grazed for some distance before he comes to a halt.

Blade - it gives rise to a clean-cut wound which is usually deepest at its starting. Tailing of the wound indicates the direction of injury. Length is the biggest parameter of this type of wound.

Lathi- It is a blunt force injury giving rise to a patterned abrasion with 2 parallel lines and a normal unbruised area on site of impact or stick/lathi. The lathi forces the blood from the site of impact to either side which gives rise to tramline appearance.

The above image shows a chop wound inflicted on scalp.

The above image shows a schematic illustrating heaping up of epidermis in a graze abrasion or brush burn

The above image shows production of a tramline bruise associated with a lathi strike

questions.text: A patient with parathyroid deficiency, 10 days after inadvertent damage to the parathyroid glands during thyroid surgery would probably have:

choices.text: High plasma phosphate, High Ca2+ levels and tetanus.
Low plasma Ca2+ level, tetany, and Trousseau sign.
Low plasma phosphate and high Ca2+ levels and bone demineralization.
Increased muscular excitability, a high plasma Ca2+ level, and bone demineralization

questions.solution:
Parathyroid hormone deficiency leads to low Ca+2 level, tetany and Trousseau sign.

(Please differentiate with tetanus which is caused by infection with the bacteria Clostridium tetani)

Actions of PTH include

  • PTH stimulates bone resorption, causing the release of calcium into the extracel­lular fluid;
  • PTH increases reabsorption of calcium and decreases phosphate reabsorption by the renal tubules, leading to reduced excretion of calcium and increased excretion of phosphate; and
  • PTH is necessary for the conversion of 25­-hydroxycholecalciferol to 1,25­ dihydroxycholecalciferol, which, in turn, increases calcium absorption by the intestines. 

So, a deficiency of PTH would lead to low Ca+2 levels and high Phosphate levels. 

Symptoms and signs of hypocalcemia - mild circumoral or digital numbness and paresthesia, carpopedal spasm, or laryngeal spasms and cardiac arrhythmias. Chvostek and Trousseaus sign may be elicited. ECG changes may show QT prolongation or QRS changes.

The signs of tetany in humans include Chvostek sign, a quick contraction of the ipsilateral facial muscles elicited by tapping over the facial nerve at the angle of the jaw, and Trousseau sign, a spasm of the muscles of the upper extremity that causes flexion of the wrist and thumb.

Management - Acute symptomatic hypocalcemia is an emergency and must be treated with IV and oral calcium and vitamin D replacement. 10 ml IV calcium gluconate 10% is given slowly. Supplemental Magnesium may also be required due to the synergestic actions of calcium and magnesium. 

A hand being held similarly to Trousseau's sign (below).

questions.text: An MRI of an elderly female patient with new-onset seizures, revealed a large mass with central necrosis and surrounding edema, crossing the corpus callosum into both frontal lobes. Subsequently, she underwent surgical resection of the mass. Microscopy is shown below. Identify the given condition.
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with MRI findings and microscopy showing pseudopalisading pattern is strongly suggestive of glioblastoma or grade IV astrocytoma.

Glioblastoma affects people usually in the sixth or seventh decade. These tumors may arise de novo or may result from a malignant transformation of lower-grade astrocytomas. Mutations of isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH), PTEN, and epidermal growth factor receptor gene (EGFR) are implicated in the pathogenesis. The majority of the tumors (90%) have IDH wild-type mutation and the remaining have IDH mutant type.

Clinically, the patient presents with headaches, seizures due to raised intracranial pressure, or focal neurologic deficits depending upon the site involved. 

Grossly, glioblastomas are found to infiltrate the brain tissue and are poorly delineated. Microscopically, they are composed of poorly differentiated pleomorphic astrocytic cells with nuclear atypia and high mitotic activity. Necrosis and florid microvascular proliferation are characteristic. They exhibit pseudopalisading (a dense arrangement of tumor cells) lining up around the foci of tumor necrosis.

 

They preferentially spread along the condensed white matter tracts such as corticospinal tracts and corpus callosum and can give rise to the butterfly glioma, involving the contralateral hemisphere.

The image given below shows MRI findings seen in glioblastomas. Note the butterfly morphology of the tumor:

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms produces superantigen?
questions.solution:
Streptococcus pyogenes produces streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin (SPE), which is a superantigen.

Superantigens are protein toxins that stimulate large numbers of T cells, irrespective of antigen specificity. They bind to the class II MHC molecule outside the peptide-binding groove and Vβ region of the TCR.

Some examples of superantigens are staphylococcal enterotoxins, toxic shock syndrome toxin, and group A streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin.

The below image shows the binding of superantigen to T-cell receptor.

questions.text: A patient who was on warfarin therapy for atrial fibrillation is prescribed a cephalosporin antibiotic for the treatment of a lower respiratory tract infection. He reports back to the hospital after having developed hemarthrosis. Which of the following cephalosporins is likely to have caused this?
questions.solution:
The cephalosporin antibiotic most likely to have caused hemarthrosis in this patient on warfarin therapy is cefoperazone.

Cephalosporins containing a methylthiotetrazole (NMTT) group can prolong the prothrombin time. This results in clinically significant bleeding in patients already on anticoagulant therapy or having vitamin K deficiency. 

This is because NMTT cephalosporins inhibit the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase in the liver, which is the key enzyme for vitamin K-dependent carboxylation, a posttranslational modification that is essential for the biological functions of coagulation factors. 
NMTT group containing cephalosporins include latamoxef, cefmenoxime, cefoperazone, cefotetan, cefamandole.

Vitamin K epoxide reductase is also the target of anticoagulants like warfarin. Oral administration of vitamin K can prevent this problem.

questions.text: Antigen binding to MHC class I activates which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
Antigen binding to major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I activates cytotoxic T cells.

The major histocompatibility complex (MHC), is a genetic locus that encodes a group of antigens. The MHC molecules also bind peptide antigens and present them to the T cells. The human MHC is called the human leukocyte antigen (HLA) complex.

The MHC class I proteins present their antigens to CD8 T cells (cytotoxic T cells). The antigens bound to MHC class II proteins activate the CD4 T cells( T helper cells). There is no cross recognition between the T cells and MHC classes. This is known as MHC restriction. For example, a CD4 T cell would recognize an antigen presented by a macrophage only if it's bound to MHC class II molecules. 

Other options:

Option B - B cells interact with an antigen based on the immunoglobulin surface receptors on the B cell. The receptor along with the antigen is embodied and degraded and the peptides produced are returned to the cell surface. It is then bound to the MHC class II molecules present on the cell surface. This is then recognized by CD4 T cells. Ultimately, the B cells are stimulated to proliferate and differentiate into plasma cells which secrete antibodies. 

Option C - Natural killer (NK) cells are granular lymphocytes that confer innate immunity by protecting against viruses and intracellular pathogens. 

Option D - T helper cells are responsible for the production of cytokines which activate the humoral and cell-mediated branches of immunity. These cells will recognize only those antigens that are presented along with MCH class II molecules on APC such as macrophages and B lymphocytes.

Related Pearl: MHC Classes I and II

MHC Class I

MHC Class II

Expressed on all nucleated cells and platelets

Mainly expressed on cells that present ingested antigens and respond to T-cell help (macrophages, B lymphocytes, and dendritic cells).

Consist of a polymorphic α, or heavy, chain linked noncovalently to the nonpolymorphic protein called β2-microglobulin

Heterodimer consisting of a noncovalently associated α chain and β chain, both of which are polymorphic.

The α chains are encoded by three genes, designated HLA-A, HLA-B, and HLA-C

Encoded in a region called HLA-D, which has three subregions: HLA-DP, HLA-DQ, and HLA-DR.

Display peptides that are derived from proteins, such as viral and tumor antigens

Present antigens that are internalized into vesicles, and are typically derived from extracellular microbes and soluble proteins

Peptide-class I complexes are recognized by CD8+ T cells, which function as CTLs.

Class II-peptide complex is recognized by CD4+ T cells

 

 

 

Image – MHC Class I and Class II molecules

questions.text: Which of the following jugular venous pressure (JVP) waves corresponds to the isovolumetric contraction phase of the cardiac cycle?
questions.solution:
The c wave of jugular venous pressure wave corresponds to the isovolumetric contraction phase in the cardiac cycle.

During isovolumetric contraction, the ventricles start contracting with valves closed. This leads to bulging of the tricuspid valve. This bulging increases pressure in the right atrium which is transmitted to the right internal jugular vein. This appears as a c wave in jugular venous pressure (JVP) tracing.

JVP measured in the internal jugular vein (IJV) is a reflection of the right atrial pressure. IJV is preferred because it is not valved and is in direct line with superior vena cava and right atrium.

The waveforms seen in a normal JVP are:

  • a wave corresponds to atrial contraction and occurs just after the P wave (on ECG) and just before the first heart sound.
  • c wave represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular systole.
  • x descent corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.
  • v wave represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at the second heart sound.
  • y descent represents passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle after tricuspid valve opening.

 The Wiggers diagram given below correlates JVP with other aspects of cardiac cycle. 

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: A specimen of the posterior surface of the larynx is kept in an anatomy practical exam and a structure is marked with red. What would be the action of the structure?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the posterior view of the larynx and the marked muscle is the posterior cricoarytenoid. Its action is to abduct the vocal cords and open the glottis. The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is identified by its origin from the posterior surface of the cricoid. 

The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle arises from the posterior surface of the cricoid lamina and is attached to the upper and posterior surfaces of the muscular processes of the ipsilateral arytenoids. It is innervated by a branch of the recurrent laryngeal nerve. They are active in the production of unvoiced sounds.

The image below shows the intrinsic muscles of the larynx.
