questions.text: Which of the following muscle is supplied by the structure marked as D in the following image?
questions.solution:
The structure marked as D is the recurrent laryngeal nerve. It supplies posterior cricoarytenoid muscle which is an intrinsic muscle of the larynx. All the intrinsic muscles of the larynx are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve except for cricothyroid, which is supplied by the external laryngeal nerve.

In the given image, other structures marked are:

  • A – vagus
  • B – Sympathetic trunk
  • C – Phrenic nerve

The cervical part of sympathetic trunk lies anterior to longus colli and longus capitis muscles (enclosed in prevertebral fascia) and posterior to the common carotid artery. Sympathetic trunk lies outside the carotid sheath.

Other options:

Option A: Trapezius is supplied by the spinal accessory nerve (CN XI).

Option C: Cricothyroid is supplied by the external laryngeal nerve.

Option D: Diaphragm is supplied by the phrenic nerve.

questions.text: What type of data does the image given below represent?
questions.solution:
The given image is of a histogram. It is used to represent frequency distributions of continuous quantitative data.

Nominal and ordinal data can be represented by a bar chart.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following is a histogram of cholesterol levels from the Framingham Heart Study.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is breathing quietly. He then inhales as much air as possible and exhales as much air as he can, producing the spirogram shown in the figure. What are the Functional residual capacity and expiratory reserve volume, respectively?
questions.solution:
Expiratory Reserve Volume = Functional Residual Capacity - Residual Volume

In the given spirogram,

  • Functional Residual Capacity = 3L
  • Residual Volume = 1L

Therefore,

Expiratory Reserve Volume = Functional Residual Capacity – Residual Volume = 3-1 = 2

Note:

The residual volume is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after the most forceful expiration.

The functional residual capacity equals the expiratory reserve volume plus the residual volume. This capacity is the amount of air that remains in the lungs at the end of normal expiration

The expiratory reserve volume is the maximum extra volume of air that can be expired by forceful expiration after the end of a normal tidal expiration.

Related Pearl: Lung volumes and capacities

Measurement

Normal Value

Tidal volume (TV)

The amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration (or the amount that moves out with each expiration) during quiet breathing

500–750 mL.

Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)

The air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the TV

∼3 L

Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)

The volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration

∼1.1 L

Residual volume (RV)

The air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort

∼1.2 L

∼5.8 L

∼4.5 L

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with complaints of fever, ear pain, and difficulty in swallowing for 1 week. On examination, there is testicular swelling and his jaw is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with fever, ear pain, parotid swelling, and testicular swelling is suggestive of mumps.

Mumps is caused by RNA paramyxovirus. It is spread from person to person via droplets from clinical and subclinical cases. The incubation period is 12-21 days. The virus appears in the saliva from up to 7 days before to as long as 7 days after the onset of parotid swelling.

The patient presents with prodrome lasting 1-2 days consisting of fever, headache, and vomiting. After the prodrome, unilateral or bilateral parotitis develops, which is tender. It may be associated with ipsilateral ear pain. Ingestion of sour or acidic foods may enhance pain.

It can be prevented by administering live attenuated, MMR vaccine at 15-18 months and 5 years.

Complications of mumps:

  • Aseptic meningitis or meningoencephalitis
  • Epididymo-orchitis which is usually unilateral. Seen in post-pubertal males
  • Oophoritis
  • Other complications include pancreatitis and myocarditis

Meningoencephalitis/aseptic meningitis can occur before, along with, or after parotitis. Most commonly, it manifests 5 days after parotitis. It can present with headaches, neck stiffness, and drowsiness.

*Note: Non-mumps parotitis can be caused by:

  • Epstein-Barr virus - causes infectious mononucleosis
  • Coxsackievirus - causes herpangina
  • Parainfluenza virus - causes croup

Related Pearl: Periods of Isolation for Selected Diseases

questions.text: Ninja-star like nuclei in the histological examination is suggestive of  ______.
questions.solution:
The ninja-star like nuclei is suggestive of dilated cardiomyopathy. 
It is seen due to truncating mutations in the titin gene. The histological examination reveals variable myocyte hypertrophy and interstitial fibrosis with nuclei that are enlarged, bizarre and hyperchromatic exhibiting a ninja-star like appearance. This may be a non-specific finding but identifying them in greater than 5% of myocytes suggests titin truncation mutations leading to dilated cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following need intervention in a newborn?
questions.solution:
Crying during micturition indicates the possibility of urinary tract infection. This requires prompt investigations and treatment with antibiotics. 

Newborns usually cry before the passage of urine due to the uncomfortable sensation of full bladder and quieten as soon as micturition starts. 

Other options:

  • Dermal Melanocytosis or Mongolian spots is a normal finding in the new born.
  • Both newborn males and females may have engorged breasts due to maternal hormonal effect which resolves spontaneously. Newborn females may also have scanty white discharge per vaginum and withdrawal vaginal bleeding. 
  • Erythema toxicum is a dermatological condition with eosinophil laden papular lesions on erythematous base dispersed all over the body which resolve spontaneously. It is the most common rash in a newborn (image shown below).

questions.text: A patient’s bladder wall tension is measured by infusing saline into the bladder through a catheter. It is noted that the tension does not change much with increasing volume. What is this phenomenon called?
questions.solution:
The bladder wall contains unitary smooth muscle. The phenomenon of little change in tension with a change in volume in smooth muscle is known as plasticity. 

Unitary smooth muscle, when stretched, initially exerts an increased tension. After some time, the tension drops. Thus, unitary smooth muscle returns to its original force of contraction in a few seconds or minutes after stretching. This property is known as plasticity. 

An example of this is bladder wall tension. When the bladder is distended with urine, the tension initially increases. After a few seconds, it drops to the original value. Thus, tension does not change much with bladder volume. This continues till a certain volume threshold is reached, following which the bladder contracts. 

Other options:

Option B: Tetanisation occurs when repeated stimulus of high frequency is applied to skeletal muscle. The successive contractions caused by the stimuli fuse and create a prolonged contraction. The force of contraction generated by a tetanised muscle fiber is large. 

Option C: Treppe, or staircase phenomenon, is seen when a muscle begins contracting after a long period of rest. The initial twitches have a lower strength of contraction, which steadily increases and reaches a plateau value. 

Option D: Recruitment of motor units produces a stronger force of contraction in skeletal muscle. It occurs when there is activation of more motor nerves and the muscle fibers they innervate.

questions.text: All the passengers coming to India were screened for COVID-19 at the airport. Which type of screening is done in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The type of screening done for the immigrants to a country is prospective screening. 

Prospective screening is done for disease control. People are examined for the benefit of others. It may lead to an early diagnosis and permit more effective treatment. It also reduces the spread of infectious diseases in the community, thereby reducing the mortality associated with the disease.

Other examples of prospective screening:

  • Screening of immigrants from infectious diseases such as tuberculosis and syphilis to protect the home population.
  • Screening for streptococcal infection to prevent rheumatic fever.

Other options:

Option A: Prescriptive screening is done for case detection. People are examined for their own benefit. Screening is initiated by medical and public health personnel and is not requested by a patient. It may lead to an early diagnosis of an unrecognized disease. Hence, appropriate treatment can be initiated immediately to arrest disease progression.

Examples of prescriptive screening:

  • Screening of infants for phenylketonuria
  • Screening of school children for visual and auditory defects.

Option B: Multiphasic screening is the combined application of two or more screening tests to a large number of people at one time. It is not cost-effective and has shown no benefit in reducing the morbidity and mortality of the population. Examples include a pregnant woman undergoing various screening tests (VDRL, HIV, HBV, etc) at a time.

Option D: Selective screening is done in high-risk groups. It is one of the most productive screening tests. Examples include MRI screening of the breast done annually in a 25-year-old woman with a first-degree relative having BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation.

questions.text: A child is born with the abnormality shown in the given image. What would you recommend for the mother in the next pregnancy?

choices.text: 400 μg of folic acid after confirmation of pregnancy

questions.solution:
The given image shows spina bifida, the most common neural tube defect (NTD). 4000 μg of folic acid periconceptionally is given to prevent NTDs in subsequent pregnancies.

The normal dose of folic acid in pregnancy is 400 μg (0.4 mg). However, the history of a previous pregnancy with an NTD raises the risk of another NTD in subsequent pregnancies. An increased dose of folic acid is therefore given prophylactically during the periconceptional period to prevent NTD in the next child.

Folic acid (daily dose):

  • Routine dosage to all normal pregnancies: 400 μg (0.4 mg)
  • Dosage for women having a previous child with NTD: 4000 μg (4 mg)

Related Pearl: Folic Acid in Pregnancy

questions.text: Killian's dehiscence is seen between___?
questions.solution:
Killian's dehiscence is seen between the cricopharyngeus and thyropharyngeus muscles.

The inferior constrictor muscle is made up of 2 parts: The upper thyropharyngeus made of oblique fibres and the lower cricopharyngeus made of transverse fibres. Between the two muscles, there is a potential gap which is called as the pharyngeal dimple or Killian's dehiscence.

This is the site of weakness in the pharyngeal wall and therefore is the potential site for the development of the diverticula- Zenker's diverticula.

Another site of weakness in the pharyngeal wall is the Laimer's triangle, which is present between the cricopharyngeus and the circular muscle of the oesophagus.

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

  • Hypopharyngeal diverticulum
  • False diverticulum
  • Pulsion diverticulum
  • Acquired diverticulum, seen in the elderly (>60 years)
  • Herniation is through the Killian’s triangle (a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor) in the posterior pharyngeal wall
  • Clinical features:
    • Dysphagia
    • Regurgitation
    • Halitosis
    • Aspiration
    • Gurgling sound during swallowing
  • Investigation of choice: Barium swallow (Lateral X rays)
  • Treatment
    • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
    • Surgical diverticulectomy
    • Marsupialization
    • Dohlman’s procedure

Zenker’s diverticulum

questions.text: Groove sign of Greenblatt is seen in ______
questions.solution:
Groove sign of Greenblatt is seen in 1/3 of cases of Lymphogranuloma venerum (LGV).

  • In the secondary stage of LGV, a painful tender lymphadenopathy is seen.
  • A groove like depression is seen between femoral and inguinal lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament.
  • It is considered as a pathognomonic sign of LGV.

Note: Pseudogroove sign of Greenblatt is seen in Donovanosis.

questions.text: Arrange the following formulations of amphotericin B (AMB) according to the increasing order of nephrotoxicity.

choices.text: Conventional-AMB < Amphotericin B lipid complex < Liposomal amphotericin B
Liposomal amphotericin B < Conventional-AMB < Amphotericin B lipid complex
Conventional-AMB < Liposomal amphotericin B < Amphotericin B lipid complex
Liposomal amphotericin B < Amphotericin B lipid complex < Conventional-AMB

questions.solution:
The correct order of nephrotoxicity with amphotericin B formulations is liposomal amphotericin B < amphotericin B lipid complex < conventional-amphotericin B.

Nephrotoxicity with amphotericin B:

All lipid formulations of amphotericin B are less nephrotoxic than conventional amphotericin B. Liposomal amphotericin B is less nephrotoxic than amphotericin B lipid complex, especially in patients with a higher risk of nephrotoxicity. Azotemia is seen in 80% of cases with C-AMB. Renal tubular acidosis and renal wasting of potassium and magnesium are seen. Nephrotoxicity can be reduced by saline loading. 

Other adverse effects:

Infusion-related reactions - It is most prominent with amphotericin B colloidal dispersion. Fever and chills following IV injection is a major acute reactions. Tachypnea, hypotension, or respiratory stridor may be also seen. Meperidine is used to shorten the reaction.

Hypochromic normocytic anemia may be seen due to decreased erythropoietin.

Headache, nausea, malaise, vomiting, and phlebitis at the site of injection is also seen.

Arachnoiditis may be seen with intrathecal injections.

Formulations of amphotericin B:

C-AMB(Conventional amphotericin B): It is formulated with bile salt deoxycholate and is given as an intravenous infusion.

ABCD(Amphotericin B colloidal dispersion): It is formed by equimolar concentrations of amphotericin B and cholesteryl sulfate.

L-AMB(Liposomal amphotericin B): Here amphotericin B is incorporated within a small liposomal vesicle.

ABLC(Amphotericin B lipid complex): It is a complex of amphotericin B with two phospholipids.

Related Pearl: Nephrotoxicity risk with Amphotericin-B formulations (decreasing order)

Nephrotoxicity Risk with Amphotericin B formulations:
  • Conventional amphotericin B (C-AMB) has the highest risk of nephrotoxicity.
  • C-AMB > Amphotericin B lipid complex > Liposomal amphotericin B.
Amphotericin B colloidal dispersion has not been compared with other lipid-based formulations. 

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs
